It shall be unlawful for any person visiting or attending theaters, concerts or other public exhibitions or public assemblies, in this city, in any manner to disturb either the performance in such exhibition, or the audience assembled, by acting in a disorderly manner, by talking, hooting, whistling or cheering in a loud and boisterous manner, or by using vulgar or indecent language, or by committing any other indecorous conduct in the presence of the audience assembled or any part thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 16-6) 
State Law reference— Public disturbance, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. 
Sec. 14-63. - Abandoned iceboxes, refrigerators and similar receptacles. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any owner or tenant of any premises within the city to allow or permit any abandoned or discarded icebox, refrigerator, trunk, chest or other receptacle or container in which a person might become imprisoned; to be or remain on such premises if such icebox, refrigerator, trunk, chest, receptacle, container or device has a virtually airtight lid, door, snap lock, latch or other locking device, without first removing such door, lid, snap lock, latch or other locking device. 
(b)  Definition. Any such container shall be considered and deemed abandoned or discarded when it is no longer used for the purpose for which it was intended, and is unattended outside of any building or structure, or is within an abandoned or unoccupied house, shed, bar or structure within the city. 
(Code 1972, § 16-1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100. 
Sec. 14-64. - Weapons. 
(a)  Drawing concealed weapons. It shall be unlawful for any person in this city to draw from a place of concealment about his person any pistol, dirk, or knife. 
(b)  Drawing weapon on another. It shall be unlawful for any person to draw on another any weapon; provided that, any person may in good faith draw in self-defense any weapon not a concealed weapon. 
(c)  Discharging firearms. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge a gun or pistol in the city, except a duly licensed gunsmith may test fire firearms in a specific facility approved for safety annually by the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 16-20) 
State Law reference— Dangerous instrumentalities and practices, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100 et seq.; Georgia Firearms and Weapons Act, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-120 et seq. 
Sec. 14-65. - Use of airguns, bow and arrow, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or use any air rifle, pellet rifle, BB gun, bow and arrows or slingshot. 
(Code 1972, § 16-15) 
Sec. 14-66. - Throwing rocks, stones. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to rock or stone any house or person in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 16-17) 
Secs. 14-67—14-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

Sec. 14-81. - Malicious mischief. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to wantonly or negligently injure or prevent the free use of any property, not his own, in this city. 
(b)  Dwellings, other structures. It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or mutilate any dwelling or similar structure in the city in any manner. 
(c)  Defacing buildings. It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, draw, carve, or cut any letters, word or words, or device, or paste or glue, or fix in any manner any cardboard or paper advertisement on, or in any way mutilate or deface any church, public building, private house, wall or fence, or sign belonging to another in the city without the permission of the owner. 
(d)  Defacing telegraph poles, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, or in any way deface any electric, telephone or telegraph pole in this city, or to break any lamp or insulator, or to throw any missile at any wire, or in any manner interfere with any pole, line, or lamp of any electric light, telephone or telegraph company in this city, to the injury or inconvenience of such company. 
(Code 1972, § 16-11) 
State Law reference— Criminal trespass and damage to property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-20 et seq. 
Sec. 14-82. - Dispossessing another of property. 
(a)  Any person who shall wilfully take possession of any goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale by any store or other mercantile establishment within the city with the intention of converting the same to his own use without paying the purchase price thereof shall be guilty of the offense of dispossessing another's property. 
(b)  Any person willfully concealing unpurchased goods or merchandise of any store or other mercantile establishment either on the premises or outside the premises of such store shall be prima facie presumed to have so concealed such article with the intention of converting the same to his own use without paying the purchase price thereof within the meaning of subsection (a) of this section. The finding of such unpurchased goods or merchandise concealed upon such person or among the belongings of such person shall be prima facie evidence of willful concealment. If such person conceals, or causes to be concealed such unpurchased goods or merchandise upon the person or among the belongings of another, the finding of the same shall also be prima facie evidence of willful concealment on the part of the person so concealing such goods. 
(Code 1972, § 16-5) 
State Law reference— Theft, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-83. - Trespass—Private property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon the property of another in the city for any purpose unless invited or authorized by the owner of the property; provided, however, that nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prohibit any person from going upon any such property for the purpose of legitimate business. 
(Code 1972, § 16-18) 
Sec. 14-84. - Same—Watershed. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon any of the lands embraced in the watershed of the waterworks of the city, or on any of the land lots thereof. 
(b)  Hunting, cutting wood, fishing, bathing. It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt or cut wood upon any of such lands constituting the watershed and to fish in any of the streams upon such land, or in the reservoir on such watershed, or to bathe therein. 
(Code 1972, § 16-19) 
Sec. 14-85. - Nuisances—Defined. 
A nuisance is anything which tends to lead to the immediate annoyance of the citizens in general, or which is manifestly injurious to the public health and safety, or tends greatly to corrupt the morals and manners of the people. 
Sec. 14-86. - Same—Abatement petition; notice to appear. 
Any person annoyed by any nuisance may apply to the superintendent of sanitation of the city by written petition, in which that person shall describe the thing complained of as a nuisance, where it is located, and the name of the person maintaining the same and pray that the same be abated. Such petition shall be investigated by the superintendent and, if such investigation shows a nuisance to exist, he may issue a summons addressed to the defendant, requiring that person to be and appear before the municipal court at a named time and place and show cause why the alleged nuisance shall be abated. A copy of such petition and summons shall be served on the defendant personally, or by leaving it with a person who is competent at the defendant's residence, by the chief of police or any police or other legal officer of the city, who shall make an entry on the original petition showing the time and method of service. 
Sec. 14-87. - Same—Hearing. 
When a rule is served as provided in section 14-86, the chief judge of the municipal court shall hear, at the time and place appointed, evidence regarding the alleged nuisance. All such hearings shall be conducted in accordance with the rules of the municipal court. 
Sec. 14-88. - Same—By owner upon order. 
If the chief judge of the municipal court of the city adjudges an object or thing a nuisance, and orders its removal, it shall be the duty of the person erecting, causing, or maintaining the nuisance to remove or abate the same within the time period prescribed by the judge. A failure or refusal of the defendant to comply with the judge's order shall be punishable as a contempt of court. 
Sec. 14-89. - Same—Performance by city; collection of cost. 
If the defendant fails or refuses to remove or abate the nuisance as directed by the chief judge of the municipal court of the city, the city manager or his designated representative shall abate the same and report the same to the city clerk, together with a bail of costs incurred. The city clerk shall thereupon issue an execution for the expenses and costs incurred against the defendant, file a lien and the chief of police shall proceed to collect such execution by levy and sale as in the case of a tax fi. fa. 
Secs. 14-90—14-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC DECENCY AND MORALS 

Sec. 14-101. - Disorderly houses. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or occupy, temporarily or otherwise, a disorderly house. For the purpose of this section, the term "disorderly house" shall be held to include any house, room or place, whether enclosed or unenclosed, in which or at which any person abides, comes together or resorts to the disturbance of the public generally, or any person in the neighborhood and engages in or commits any immoral, indecent or illegal practices or in which loud, boisterous, or annoying conduct, talking, singing, laughing, dancing or like acts which tend to harm, disturb or violate the peace, tranquility or decency of the public generally or of any person in the neighborhood or passing by. 
(Code 1972, § 16-4) 
State Law reference— Disorderly houses, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-44. 
Sec. 14-102. - Indecent dress, exposure. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to appear in any public place naked, or in an indecent or lewd dress, or to make any indecent exposure of his person, or to be guilty of any indecent or lewd act or behavior. 
(Code 1972, § 16-72) 
State Law reference— Public indecency, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8. 
Sec. 14-103. - Obscene publications, exhibitions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit, sell or offer for sale, any obscene, vulgar or licentious book, picture or painting of any character whatever, or to exhibit or perform in any hall, house or public place in the city, any indecent, immoral or lewd play or dance, or to sing to a public audience any sacrilegious, indecent, vulgar or lewd song. 
(Code 1972, § 16-73) 
State Law reference— Distributing obscene materials, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-80 et seq. 
Sec. 14-104. - Obscene movies. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, manager or agent in charge of any motion picture theater in the city to exhibit or allow to be exhibited in such theater any indecent, immoral or obscene motion pictures. 
(Code 1972, § 16-74) 
Sec. 14-105. - Houses of ill fame. 
(a)  Living in, frequenting. It shall be unlawful for any person to live in or frequent houses of ill fame in this city. 
(b)  Permitting occupancy. It shall be unlawful for the owner or agent of the owner, to rent, or cause to be rented, or occupy or cause to be occupied, any house or portion of a house, to be used as a house of ill fame in this city; or for any owner or agent of such owner, of any house in this city, to suffer or permit any woman of ill fame to occupy such house in this city, for the purpose of adultery or fornication, for the space of two days after the same shall have been adjudged a house of ill fame by the court; or for any person to occupy or allow to be occupied any house, or portion of a house, to be used as a house of ill fame. 
(c)  Ejection of occupants. Whenever it develops upon the trial of any cases made under any of the foregoing provisions, that any house is a house of ill fame, and is so adjudged by the municipal court, it shall be the duty of the police to eject the occupants. 
(d)  Proof of violation. Circumstances from which it may be reasonably inferred that any house is inhabited by disorderly persons or by persons of immoral character and notoriously bad fame, shall be sufficient to establish the fact that such house is a house of ill fame. 
(Code 1972, § 16-75) 
State Law reference— Prostitution and related offenses, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-10. 
Chapter 15 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of city to acquire, operate, etc., parks, etc., § 1.4(12); authority to regulate and control erection, control, etc., of signs, etc., along roadside areas, § 1.4(18). 
State Law reference— Power to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(5); authority to construct and operate parks, swimming pools, golf courses, recreation grounds and buildings used for sports, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; establishment of recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.; state commission on physical fitness created, O.C.G.A. § 50-12-40 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 15-1—15-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-166 et seq. 

Sec. 15-26. - Establishment; purpose. 
There is hereby created a commission to be known and designated as the City of Newnan Parks Commission and to be referred to in this article as the "commission" for the purposes of planning the development of and recommending placement of the improvements and structures in the city's public parks; establishing a recommended schedule for the maintenance of the city's parks; and to generally improve the general welfare and health of the people of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 2-112; Ord. No. 23-90, § I, 9-24-90) 
Sec. 15-27. - Composition; terms; compensation. 
(a)  The parks commission shall consist of seven members who shall be appointed by the mayor and city council who shall serve for a term of three years. Each member shall be a resident of the city during their term of office. The current members of the commission shall serve the remainder of the term for which he/she has been appointed. The new member of the commission shall be appointed for a term of three years. 
Vacancies in office during the term of any appointment caused by death, resignation, disqualification or otherwise shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and city council in the same manner as the person was appointed whose office has become vacant. 
(b)  The city manager shall appoint a member of the city staff to act as a liaison between the commission and the city. 
(c)  The members of the commission shall serve without compensation. However, they shall be entitled to be reimbursed for any actual expenses incurred by them in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1972, § 2-113; Ord. No. 23-90, § I, 9-24-90; Ord. No. 14-2, § I, 2-11-14 ) 
Sec. 15-28. - Duty; responsibility; authority. 
The commission created in this article shall have the duty, responsibility and authority: 
(1)  To study, develop plans, and establish goals, for the establishment, development, care, preservation, maintenance, and placement of improvements and structures in all of the city's public parks and to present such plans, as a recommendation, to the mayor and council on or before October 1 in each calendar year or as often as may be necessary to insure orderly development and operation of the city's public parks. 
(2)  To assist and coordinate its activities with the city tree commission which has the responsibility and duty to provide for and preserve the trees and shrubs in the city's public parks. 
(3)  To assist the proper authorities and officials of the city in a program to protect and maintain existing city-owned public parks. 
(4)  To assist the proper officials and make available to the general public news and information regarding the improvement, use, and maintenance of the city's public parks; to recommend from time to time as necessary ordinances and other programs that will be beneficial to improve, protect and maintain such parks. 
(Code 1972, § 2-114; Ord. No. 23-90, § I, 9-24-90) 
Sec. 15-29. - Officers' meetings. 
Upon appointment of the initial commission by mayor and council, the commission shall meet and elect one of its members as chairman and one of its members as secretary. The commission shall then provide for the rules and procedure for the holding of regular and special meetings of the commission as deemed advisable and necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 2-115; Ord. No. 23-90, § I, 9-24-90) 
Secs. 15-30—15-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-166 et seq. 

Sec. 15-71. - Established. 
There is hereby established a department of parks and recreation for the city. 
(Code 1972, § 18-1) 
Sec. 15-72. - Control of parks. 
General control over the lands and property in the city now used as public parks and places or hereafter acquired, is hereby vested in the city parks and recreation department. 
(Code 1972, § 18-2) 
Sec. 15-73. - General powers and duties. 
The parks and recreation department shall, subject to the supervision and review of the city manager, lay out, establish, beautify and improve the parks of the city, and shall have authority generally to maintain and carry forward improvements, as money may, from time to time, be appropriated by the city council or received from the proceeds of bond issues, private contributions or other sources. 
(Code 1972, § 18-3) 
Sec. 15-74. - Power relative to trees, and other plants in streets and sidewalks. 
Subject to the supervision and review of the city manager, the parks and recreation department shall have general control over all trees, flowers, vines, plants and shrubs in and upon the streets, alleys and sidewalks of the city, with power to plant, care for, trim, cut, remove and transplant or otherwise dispose of the same. 
(Code 1972, § 18-4) 
Sec. 15-75. - Appointment of director. 
The city manager shall appoint a director of parks and recreation who shall be confirmed by the city council in accordance with charter provisions. 
(Code 1972, § 18-6) 
Sec. 15-76. - Director's police power. 
For the purpose of carrying out his duties, the director of parks and recreation shall have the power to issue citations for violations of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 18-7) 
Secs. 15-77—15-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 15-96. - Permission required to cut, plant, remove, etc., trees and other plants in streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, cut, trim, prune, transplant, remove or interfere with any tree, flower, vine, plant or shrub in or upon any of the streets, alleys, or sidewalks within the city, or any boxing, pot or other thing provided for the protection thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 18-5) 
Sec. 15-97. - Destroying or injuring park property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, break, mutilate, mark, deface or in any other manner destroy or injure any public property, real or personal, belonging to or used by the city or the park and recreation department in, upon, or about any of the public parks of the city or in the municipal swimming pools. 
(Code 1972, § 18-9) 
Sec. 15-98. - Closing hours. 
(a)  Every public park in the city and every place of amusement therein shall be closed to all persons at 12:00 midnight every day and shall not be re-opened before 6:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(b)  All persons within the bounds of such parks or amusement places therein shall vacate the same by 12:00 midnight and shall not remain therein or be therein after that hour or between that hour and 6:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any such park or amusement place therein after 12:00 midnight of any day and before 6:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(Code 1972, § 18-8) 
Sec. 15-99. - Posting or distributing advertising matter or littering prohibited in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to affix any bill, sign, or notice on any tree, building or fixture in any of the parks of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute any handbills or dodgers or scatter or place any paper, books, refuse or trash of any kind in or about any of the public parks of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 18-10) 
Sec. 15-100. - Pollution or disturbance of springs, ponds, etc., in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to pollute or disturb any spring, branch, pond or other water within the confines of any of the parks belonging to the city by throwing sticks, stones, refuse or trash therein or by washing the person or objects in such waters. 
(Code 1972, § 18-11) 
Sec. 15-101. - Killing or catching animals, fowl or fish in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to kill or catch, or pursue, with such intent, any animal, fish or bird, or to rob or destroy any bird's nest in any park. 
(Code 1972, § 18-12) 
Sec. 15-102. - Discharging firearms, firecrackers, etc., or throwing missiles in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to handle or discharge any firearm, firecracker, air gun, slingshot or other explosive, noisy or destructive article or substance, or throw any stone or other missile in, about or across any of the parks belonging to the city. 
(Code 1972, § 18-13) 
Sec. 15-103. - Drinking liquor, making noise and other disorderly or disturbing conduct in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any spirituous liquors, be in an intoxicated condition, make any loud or unnecessary noises, engage in noisy disputes or conversations, engage in any indecent or lewd acts or behavior, or in any other manner disturb the public peace, quiet and order in or within the vicinity of any of the parks of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 18-14) 
Sec. 15-104. - Certain persons prohibited in parks. 
No person of loose or disreputable character shall walk or loiter in or about the parks or public places of the city to the annoyance of peaceable citizens. 
(Code 1972, § 18-15) 
Sec. 15-105. - Scheduling of organized games and assemblages in parks; permission required for erection of booth or stand or sale of articles in parks. 
The director of parks and recreation shall schedule the use of all parks and public places for organized games, assemblages or gatherings. No person shall be allowed to erect any booth or stand or to sell any article within the limits of any of the public parks without the permission of the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1972, § 18-16) 
Sec. 15-106. - Curfew for occupancy of C. J. Smith Memorial Park and surrounding streets. 
A curfew of 10:30 p.m. is hereby put into effect for the use and occupancy of the C. J. Smith Memorial Park. It shall be unlawful for any person to use or occupy the C. J. Smith Memorial Park after 10:30 p.m. It shall further be unlawful for any person not a resident of Farmer Street, Glen Street, or Murray Street to loiter on such streets or in parked cars thereon after 10:30 p.m. 
(Code 1972, § 18-16.1) 
Sec. 15-107. - Use of motorized vehicles in C. J. Smith City Park. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, use or ride on any motorized vehicle including motorcycles, minibikes, go-carts, or automobiles within the limits and boundaries of the C. J. Smith City Park. Any person violating this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-14. 
(Code 1972, § 18-16.2) 
Secs. 15-108—15-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MUNICIPAL SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 15-131. - Supervision, control and management. 
The municipal swimming pools shall be under the general supervision, control and management of the director of parks and recreation, subject to the provisions and regulations provided and authorized under the general supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 18-17) 
Sec. 15-132. - Employment and discharge of managers and other employees. 
The director of parks and recreation shall name and designate managers of the swimming pools and such other employees and attendants as may be deemed necessary, and shall have full power and authority to employ and discharge them. 
(Code 1972, § 18-18) 
Sec. 15-133. - Records, accounts and reports of managers. 
(a)  The managers of the swimming pools shall be required to keep a complete and accurate system of books and records showing: 
(1)  All personal properties in their custody, or in use by the swimming pools and skating rink. 
(2)  All receipts and disbursements. 
(b)  They shall fully account for such properties and moneys, making a complete report to the city clerk and treasurer at the close of each day. 
(Code 1972, § 18-19) 
Sec. 15-134. - Qualifications for lifeguards. 
Any person engaged as the chief lifeguard at a municipal swimming pool shall be an American Red Cross first-aid and water safety instructor and shall hold certificates that will enable him to pass pupils in the senior first-aid course and the courses qualifying them to become senior and junior life savers. Other lifeguards who may be employed at a municipal swimming pool shall hold certificates showing that they are qualified American Red Cross senior life savers and that they have successfully passed and hold certificates for the standard American Red Cross first-aid course. No person not having the foregoing qualifications shall be employed as a lifeguard. 
(Code 1972, § 18-20) 
Sec. 15-135. - When to be open; lifeguard to be on duty; entering while closed prohibited. 
The municipal swimming pools shall be kept open during specified hours, notice of which shall be posted at some conspicuous place at the swimming pools. At least one lifeguard shall be on duty at all times while the pool is open for use. It shall be unlawful, except during the open hours, for any person to enter the water of such pools or enter any enclosure provided for the purpose of keeping people away from the pool. 
(Code 1972, § 18-21) 
Sec. 15-136. - Small children to be properly attended. 
It shall be unlawful for any person having in his care any small child to permit such child to enter any municipal swimming pool unless such child is properly attended by the person charged with the care of such child. 
(Code 1972, § 18-22) 
Chapter 16 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; businesses, Ch. 6; environment, Ch. 10; utilities, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt plans and exercise the power of zoning, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 4; The Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local government zoning powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2; conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.; effect of zoning laws on covenants running with the land, O.C.G.A. § 44-5-60. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Position of city planner established; planner's duties. 
The position of city planner is hereby established and his duties shall be as prescribed by the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 19-1) 
Sec. 16-2. - Chattahoochee-Flint Regional Development Commission. 
The city shall be a member of the Chattahoochee-Flint Regional Development Commission. 
(Code 1972, § 19-2; Ord. No. 14-88, 8-22-88) 
Sec. 16-3. - Zoning and subdivision ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance relating to zoning or any ordinance regulating subdivisions, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 19-3) 
Secs. 16-4—16-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 16-31. - Purpose; creation. 
In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the city of Newnan Planning Commission, hereinafter referred to as "the planning commission," is hereby created and established as authorized by the provisions of article IX, section II, paragraph IV of the 1982 Constitution of the State of Georgia and the Zoning Procedures Law of 1985. 
(Code 1972, § 19-13; Ord. No. 29-90, § I, 12-19-90) 
Sec. 16-32. - Membership; appointment, terms, compensation, removal. 
The planning commission shall consist of seven members who shall be residents of the city and appointed by the city council. The terms of the members shall be for four years except that current members shall serve the terms to which they have been appointed. Two new members shall be appointed: one shall be appointed for a term of two years and the other shall be appointed for a term of four years. Should a vacancy occur in the membership it shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and city council, which shall also have authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, at a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. Failure of any regular member to attend a minimum of 75 percent of all meetings and workshops of the planning commission during any calendar year shall result in automatic removal from membership on the planning commission. 
(Code 1972, § 19-14; Ord. No. 29-90, § I, 12-19-90; Ord. No. 5-94, § I, 4-12-94) 
Sec. 16-33. - Organization; staff. 
The planning commission shall elect its chairman from among its members. The term of the chairman shall be one year from eligibility for reelection. The term of the chairman shall commence the first meeting of the next calendar year after his election. The secretary of the commission shall be the city planner. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may, with approval of city council, contract with the state planning commission and with city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. 
(Code 1972, § 19-15; Ord. No. 29-90, § I, 12-19-90) 
Sec. 16-34. - Meetings, rules, records. 
The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public, and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. Three members of the planning commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1972, § 19-16; Ord. No. 29-90, § I, 12-19-90) 
Sec. 16-35. - Finances. 
The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amount appropriated for the purpose by the city council. 
(Code 1972, § 19-17; Ord. No. 29-90, § I, 12-19-90) 
Sec. 16-36. - Powers and duties. 
The planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities as directed by city council, as contained in this Code and as set forth in the Zoning Procedures Law of 1985. Additional powers, duties and responsibilities deemed necessary by the city council shall be as follows: 
(1)  To make studies and project plans for the improvement of the city, with a view toward its future development and extension, and to recommend to the city council all matters for the development and advancement of the city's facilities, layout and appearance. 
(2)  To make plans and maps of the whole or any portion of the city. 
(3)  To confer with and advise property owners pertaining to location and erection of structures in order to promote conformity to the overall city plan. 
(4)  To assist all other municipal and governmental agencies, and especially the city council, in formulating and executing proper plans of municipal development. 
(5)  To plan and recommend the location, plan, and extent of city alleyways, viaducts, bridges, parkways, parks, playgrounds, airports, automobile parking places and other public properties, and of public utilities, including railroads, railroad depots and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned, for water, lights, sanitation, sewerage, sewage disposal, drainage, flood control, transportation, communication, power, and for the removal, relocation, widening, extension, narrowing, vacation, abandonment or change of use of any of the foregoing public places, works, buildings, facilities or utilities. 
(6)  To select and recommend to the city council routes of streets, avenues, and boulevards, and particularly to investigate and recommend the opening, widening, or abandonment of streets, avenues, boulevards, and alleys or the changing thereof to conform with the city's system, present and future, of boulevards, streets, avenues, alleyways, parks and parkways. 
(7)  To investigate, consider and report to the city council upon the layout or platting of new subdivisions of the city. 
(8)  To recommend to the city council for adoption and promulgation rules and regulations governing plats and subdivision of land within the corporate limits of the city; to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the community, and the safe, orderly and healthful development of such community. 
(9)  To recommend plans to the city council for improving, developing, expanding and beautifying the parks, parkways, and streams and to cooperate with the city council and other agencies and commissions of the city in devising, establishing, locating, improving, selecting, expanding and maintaining the public parks, parkways, playgrounds and places for public recreation. 
(10)  To suggest plans for clearing the city of deteriorated and blighted areas. 
(Code 1972, § 19-18; Ord. No. 29-90, § I, 12-19-90) 
Secs. 16-37—16-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT 

Sec. 16-51. - Created; supervision; divisions within department. 
There is hereby created an administrative department of the city under the general supervision of the city manager, which shall be known as the department of community development. There shall be the following divisions within the department: 
(1)  Planning. 
(2)  Zoning. 
(3)  [Reserved.] 
(4)  Community development. 
(Code 1972, § 2-116; Ord. No. 10-6, § I, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 16-52. - Position of director established. 
There is hereby established the position of director of the department of community development, an administrative officer, who shall be appointed by, and be responsible to the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 2-117) 
Sec. 16-53. - Powers, duties of director. 
The director of the department of community development, on behalf of the department shall: 
(1)  Supervise and direct all employees of the department. 
(2)  Advise the city council through the city manager on all matters affecting the physical growth and development of the city when requested and required to do so. 
(3)  Issue or delegate the responsibility to the various division personnel to issue all permits, certificates, orders and notifications resulting from decisions on ordinances administered by the department. 
(4)  Recommend action on subdivision plats to the city manager. 
(5)  Serve as liaison between the city and the Newnan-Coweta Planning Commission. 
(6)  Establish liaison and close working relationships with the administrative offices of the city and other local government agencies and institutions in order for plans of the area to be coordinated. 
(7)  Promote the realization of the comprehensive plan. 
(8)  Provide information to the public in community development problems and develop a program of citizen participation. 
(9)  Provide information to the zoning board of appeals and the Newnan-Coweta Planning Commission. 
(10)  The director shall integrate all individual projects or programs and develop plans to insure harmonious and integrated planning for the area concerned. 
(11)  The director shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed from time to time, by the city manager. 
(Code 1972, § 2-117(1)) 
Sec. 16-54. - Planning division. 
The planning division of the department of community development shall: 
(1)  Undertake research studies and prepare and recommend a comprehensive plan, including the development of more detailed plans and programs based on the comprehensive plan for area renewal, conservation, rehabilitation or redevelopment. 
(2)  Review all annexation and disconnection proposals and submit written recommendations to the director. If the recommendation is for approval of an annexation, the director shall review and submit his written comments to the city manager and the city council on the zoning classification for the annexed tract. 
(3)  Review and submit written comments to the director upon all proposals to amend the zoning ordinance, the subdivision ordinance, official map and standards ordinance, and such other ordinances as the city council or city manager may refer to the department. From time to time make recommendations for the updating and revisions of the ordinances concerned or for the adoption of new ordinances related thereto. 
(4)  Maintain the official map and keep it up to date. 
(5)  Prepare and recommend, and assist other departments of the city in the development of specific projects intended to complement the comprehensive plan. 
(Code 1972, § 2-117(2)) 
Sec. 16-55. - Zoning division. 
The zoning division of the department of community development shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Administer and enforce the zoning ordinance and conduct inspections of all buildings, structures, signs, and uses of any premises to determine compliance and/or noncompliance with the terms of the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Maintain current the zoning district map. 
(3)  Maintain permanent and current records of the zoning ordinance including, but not limited to, official actions on all amendments, special uses, variations, appeals, and applications therefor. 
(4)  Administer and enforce the subdivision ordinance and the official map and standards ordinances, including the review of all plats of subdivisions, and submit a written report and recommendation for approval or disapproval to the city manager. 
(5)  Prepare and submit to the city manager an annual report on the work of the zoning board of appeals, and the effectiveness of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1972, § 2-117(3)) 
Sec. 16-56. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-6, § II, adopted April 13, 2010, repealed § 16-56, which pertained to urban renewal division and derived from Code 1972, § 2-117(4). The user's attention is directed to § 16-61 et seq. 
Sec. 16-57. - Community development division. 
The community development division of the department of community development shall develop long range plans for development of the city in accordance with federal regulations and which are approved by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1972, § 2-117(5)) 
Sec. 16-58. - Staffing; expenditures. 
The city manager may employ or assign to the department of community development persons who are qualified by training and/or experience to perform the work of the department and also employ technical and professional consultants as desired and needed to perform specific work for the department. No expenditure pursuant to this article may be made or liability incurred without a prior appropriation therefor in the annual appropriation ordinance. 
(Code 1972, § 2-117(6)) 
Secs. 16-59, 16-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITY OF NEWNAN URBAN REDEVELOPMENT AGENCY 

Sec. 16-61. - Establishment: purpose. 
In accordance with the authority granted the city in O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq., there is hereby created an agency to be known and designated as the City of Newnan Urban Redevelopment Agency and to be herein referred to as "NURA" for the purposes of implementing and regulating the components of the city's plan for redevelopment. 
(Ord. No. 10-6, § III, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 16-62. - Composition; terms. 
The NURA shall consist of nine commissioners, residents of the City of Newnan, and otherwise eligible for appointment, who shall be appointed by the mayor and city council who shall serve for a term of three years. Each commissioner shall be a resident of the city during their term of office. The initial group of commissioners of the agency shall be appointed for terms of office as follows: three commissioners for a term of one year, three commissioners for a term of two years, and three commissioners for a term of three years. Each councilmember shall have the opportunity to nominate for appointment to the agency one commissioner. The mayor shall have the opportunity to nominate for appointment to the agency three commissioners, two of whom shall be current members of the Newnan Housing Authority Board of Directors serving concurrently with their appointment to this agency. 
Each commissioner shall hold office until his or her successor has been appointed and has qualified. 
For inefficiency, neglect of duty, or misconduct in office, a commissioner may be removed, but only after a hearing. He or she shall be given a copy of the charges as least ten days prior to such hearing and shall have an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel. 
Vacancies caused by death, resignation, disqualification of otherwise shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 10-6, § III, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 16-63. - Compensation. 
The members of the agency shall serve without compensation. However, they shall be entitled to be reimbursed for any actual expenses incurred by them, including travel expenses, in the discharge of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 10-6, § III, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 16-64. - Duty; responsibility; authority. 
The agency shall have the duties, responsibility, and authority to exercise all urban redevelopment powers set out in O.C.G.A. §§ 36-61-17 and 36-61-18, as such sections may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 10-6, § III, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 16-65. - Officers; meetings. 
Upon appointment of the initial agency by mayor and council, and designation by the mayor of one of its commissioners as chairman and one of its commissioners as vice-chairman, the agency shall meet and elect one of its commissioners as secretary. The agency shall then provide for the rules and procedures for the holding of regular and special meetings of the agency as deemed advisable and necessary. 
A majority of the commissioners shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting business and exercising the powers of the agency and for all other purposes. Action may be taken by the agency upon a vote of a majority of the commissioners present, unless in any case the bylaws require a larger number. 
(Ord. No. 10-6, § III, 4-13-10) 
Chapter 17 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-28, adopted September 8, 2003, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 17, §§ 17-1—17-10 and 17-36—17-43, and added a new ch. 17, §§ 17-1—17-12, 17-31—17-48, 17-56—17-62, 17-71—17-73, 17-81—17-88. Former ch. 17 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1972, §§ 12-2, 12-3, and 12-9—12-14; Ord. No. 2-90, adopted January 8, 1990; Ord. No. 12-90, adopted July 9, 1990; and Ord. No. 22-93, adopted October 25, 1993. 
Charter reference— Authority of city to establish garbage fees, § 1.4(24). 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 10-26 et seq.; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference— Authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3; Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; hazardous waste disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-61 et seq.; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries pursuant to contract, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; Resource Recovery Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq.; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the words below shall have the following meanings: 
Ashes means residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings. 
Bulk waste means stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines, furniture and other waste materials excluding contractor's construction debris (but including construction debris produced by the resident), dead animals, hazardous waste (including but not limited to tires, motor oil, batteries, etc.) and refuse with weights or volumes greater than those allowed for carts. 
Cart means the receptacle designed or used for the depositing of garbage, refuse, trash, ashes, or recyclable materials as specified by the city and provided by the city contractor. 
City contractor means DL&C, Inc. d/b/a CLM or its successors or assigns. 
Commercial establishment means all retail commercial, office, industrial and institutional establishments. 
Commercial and industrial refuse means all garbage and rubbish generated by a resident at a commercial or industrial unit, but in all cases to exclude hazardous waste, such as but not limited to tires, motor oil and batteries, paint and paint thinner, gasoline, and batteries, etc. 
Commercial and industrial unit means all premises, locations or entities, public or private requiring refuse collection within the service area for which refuse collection using carts or dumpsters is deemed to be appropriate, other than a residential unit. 
Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other non-manufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. 
Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. 
Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations by a contractor, not a private resident owning the property. 
Container means the receptacle designated or used for depositing of garbage refuse, trash, ashes or recyclable materials as specified by the city and includes but is not limited to carts, dumpsters, and bins. 
Dead animals means animals or any portions thereof, weighing ten pounds or more, which have expired from any cause. 
Dumpster means a metal receptacle designed to be lifted and emptied mechanically for use primarily at commercial and industrial units. 
Dumpster, recyclable means a receptacle, designed for the depositing of recyclable material, made of any material and having a capacity of two cubic yards or more. 
Dumpster, refuse means a receptacle designed for the depositing of garbage, refuse, trash, ashes or reusable materials, made of any material and having a capacity of two cubic yards or more. 
Garbage means every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains, or other animal or vegetable matter (including, but not limited to, used metal cans and other food containers; and all putrescible or easily decomposable waste animal or vegetable matter which is likely to attract flies or rodents); except any matter included in the definition of bulky waste, construction debris, dead animals, hazardous waste or rubbish, wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; wastes from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
Hazardous waste means any chemical, compound, mixture, substance or article which is designated as "hazardous" by the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the state environmental protection division or the appropriate state, county or city agency by or pursuant to federal or state law. For purposes of this agreement, the term hazardous waste shall also include tires, batteries, paint thinner, motor oil, gasoline, paint or paint cans (excluding empty paint cans or paint cans filled with absorbents to dry out the paint) and bulky waste containing chlorofluorocarbon refrigerants or freon. 
Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. 
Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks, and includes solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. 
Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including but not limited to municipal solid waste landfills. 
Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, non-hazardous sludges or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. 
Recyclable material means material that is capable of being reused or returned to use in the form of a raw material. 
Recyclable material(s) means newspaper, glass, plastic, aluminum and cardboard. If at any time the pickup of any of the items named as recyclable materials becomes uneconomical or unrecyclable. CLM reserves the right to terminate the collection of such item. 
Refuse means garbage and rubbish generated at a residential, commercial, church, park, medical, or industrial unit and includes combustible trash, including, but not limited to, paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood furniture, bedding; noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to, metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass, crockery, other mineral waste; street rubbish, including, but not limited to, street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catchbasin dirt, contents of litter receptacles. Provided, refuse shall not include earth and wastes from building operations, nor shall it include solid wastes resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations. 
Residential refuse means all garbage and rubbish generated by a resident at a residential unit, in all cases to exclude hazardous waste or location. 
Residential unit means: 
(1)  A free-standing structure constructed for use as a residence by a person or group of persons comprising a family; or 
(2)  A residential unit within a multi-family structure for which refuse collection using carts is deemed to be appropriate. 
A residential unit shall be deemed occupied when water, waste water or domestic utility services are being supplied thereto. 
Reusable material means items or materials that can be reused with little or no value added. 
Rubbish means all used and discarded printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, mattresses, clothing, shoes and booths, combustible waste pulp and other products such as are used for packaging, or wrapping for crockery and glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic substances, and any and all other waste materials not included in the definition of bulky waste, construction debris, dead animals, garbage, hazardous waste or yard trimmings. 
Service area means the entire geographic area within the corporate limits of the city. 
Yard trimmings means wood, wood products, tree trimmings, dead plants, weeds, trees or branches thereof, chips, shavings, sawdust resulting from homeowner landscaping maintenance, leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-2. - Public works director—General duties. 
The public works director shall discharge the duties imposed upon him in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-3. - Scope of provisions. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to all public and private markets, as well as all places of business, hotels, restaurants, and all other premises, whether used for business or residential purposes. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-4. - Administrative regulation. 
The city clerk of the city shall not issue a business license or certificate of occupancy to any person, firm, or corporation which has not complied with the requirements of this chapter. The violation, noncompliance, or other violation of an administrative order issued by the public works director or the city's code enforcement officer, under this chapter, will be grounds for suspension or revocation of occupation tax certificates pursuant to article I of chapter 6. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-5. - Uncovered garbage. 
It shall be unlawful to place or permit to remain anywhere in the city any garbage or other material subject to decay, other than yard trimmings, leaves or grass, excepting in a tightly covered container. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-6. - Wind-blown refuse. 
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes, or refuse of such a material capable of being blown away by the wind anywhere in the city, other than yard trimmings, leaves or grass, except in a covered container. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-7. - Depositing garbage on the street. 
It shall be unlawful to deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any garbage, refuse or ashes on any public street, parking area, or alley in the city; provided, that this section shall not be construed to prohibit temporarily placing garbage, refuse, trash or ashes or recyclable materials in a container at an approved collection point complying with the provisions of this chapter preparatory to having such material collected and disposed of in the manner provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-8. - Collection of garbage. 
The public works director shall have charge of the collection of administration of this chapter. The collection shall be made from all premises at least once each week, provided that the material is properly stored for collection in a container complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-9. - Containers—Generally. 
(a)  All garbage shall be placed in closed containers. 
(b)  Containers shall be kept tightly covered at all times except when momentarily open to receive garbage or to have the contents removed. No container shall be so overloaded with garbage or waste matter that its cover will not fit securely. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-10. - Same—In commercial and multiple-dwelling units. 
(a)  Any apartment house, development, condominium development or town house development constructed after November 20, 1978, and any hotel, motel containing four or more units, roominghouse, business, industry, public or semiprivate establishment of any nature or kind other than a single-family, duplex or triplex residential unit shall install a garbage container meeting the following specifications: 
(1)  All containers must be steel, continuous welded and property reinforced. 
(2)  All lids will be flanged and reinforced for strength. 
(3)  Bottoms must be reinforced with a 1½-inch drain plug installed flush to bottom. 
(4)  All containers must be primed and finished with enamel or epoxy paint. 
(5)  Body dimensions as to length and height of container can vary with the size of container; however, all container widths will be 72 inches. Minimum gauges of steel shall be as follows: 
a.  12 gauge throughout. 
b.  16 gauge boxed lid. 
c.  1 5/16 ″ CRS trunion bar. 
d.  1″ × 2″ channel bracing around top. 
e.  1″ × 2″ channel bracing from trunion to rear corner. 
f.  4″ × 6″ × 10″ gauge pads on bottom four corners. 
(6)  No establishment or business named in this section shall be allowed to remove any container now in place without the approval of the public works director or his/her designee. 
(b)  The preparation and storage of commercial and multiple-dwelling refuse for collection shall be as follows: 
(1)  Before a building permit shall be issued for construction of a commercial establishment, condominium or multiple dwelling, arrangements for a storage of refuse and location of containers must be approved by the superintendent of sanitation. 
(2)  Commercial containers at existing commercial establishments and multiple dwellings serviced by city collection vehicles shall be placed at locations approved by the superintendent of sanitation for collection by the sanitation department. The city will not collect refuse from commercial establishments or multiple dwellings unless it is placed in commercial containers, properly located, except where space or other limitations dictate other arrangements, which shall be specifically approved by the superintendent of sanitation. 
(3)  Where the occupants of two or more commercial establishments share the use of a refuse can or commercial containers, it shall be the joint responsibility of the users to maintain the area surrounding such cans or containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse. 
(4)  The occupant or occupants of commercial establishments and the management of multiple dwellings serviced by commercial containers shall be responsible for maintaining the area surrounding such commercial containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse. 
(5)  All garbage and rubbish shall be free from liquid and placed in watertight paper or plastic bags with the tops secured prior to placing in commercial containers. 
(6)  Cardboard boxes shall be flattened before placed in containers. 
(7)  Commercial containers containing the following items will not be emptied until they are removed therefrom: 
a.  Large household or industrial appliances. 
b.  Furniture. 
c.  Tires. 
d.  Wooden crates. 
e.  Logs or limbs over four feet in length or four inches in diameter. 
f.  Bed springs and mattresses. 
g.  Rock, dirt, concrete blocks, sheetrock, roofing, lumber or other building materials. 
h.  Uncontainerized garbage, yard debris and household trash. 
(8)  Normal household appliances will be collected at multiple dwellings served by commercial containers, when placed adjacent to the commercial container and reported to the sanitation department. 
(9)  The user of commercial containers shall be responsible for the appearance, maintenance and serviceability of containers procured by them or placed for their use. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-11. - Garbage collection fees; invoices; penalties for late payment. 
(a)  Fees for the collection of all types of garbage shall be set by the city contractor and approved by the city council. The charges may be altered from time to time. A garbage collection fee schedule shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Invoices for any residential commercial garbage collection fees established shall be billed on a quarterly basis, and if such bill is not paid on the first day of the month following, a penalty may be added. Such penalties shall not preclude the city contractor from taking whatever action it deems necessary to enforce payment of the garbage collection fees or to discontinue service. 
(c)  Persons, firms, individuals, corporations or associations of individuals who have their collection service discontinued shall be in violation of this chapter and shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 17-12 herein. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-12. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to prosecution and the penalties set forth in section 1-14 of the Code of Ordinances. Each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation continues. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Secs. 17-13—17-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 17-31. - Supervision by city. 
The public works director and/or city's code enforcement officer shall be empowered to inspect the manner in which all garbage, refuse or ashes within the city are accumulated or disposed for compliance with this chapter. The public works director and/or city's code enforcement officer is empowered to order the discontinuance of actions in violation of this chapter or take any other action authorized to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-32. - Pickup hours regulated. 
It shall be unlawful for any commercial garbage service to pick up trash carts, dumpsters, or other such containers between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., except in the case of a bona fide emergency, the nature of which has been communicated to the public works director of the city at the time of said emergency. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-33. - Owner and operator of premises to maintain dumpster site. 
The owner and/or the person in charge of the premises for which a dumpster is permitted shall, at all times, maintain the premises in a high state of police, free and clear of litter, debris, and trash. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-34. - Garbage and recycling collection. 
All residents of the city shall participate in the garbage collection and may participate in the recycling collection by using the city contractor. All residents shall pay the monthly fees charged by the contractor for this service and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-35. - Uncovered garbage. 
It shall be unlawful to place or permit to remain anywhere in the city any garbage, or other material subject to decay, other than leaves or grass, except in a tightly covered cart or dumpster. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-36. - Consent of owner. 
It shall be unlawful to dump or place any garbage, refuse or ashes on any premises in the city without the consent of the owner of such premises. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-37. - Disposal. 
It shall be unlawful to dispose of any garbage, refuse, trash or ashes anywhere in the city except in an incinerator, or disposal device, properly constructed and operated or in a lawfully established garbage or refuse dump. Such materials not so properly disposed of shall be placed in carts or dumpsters for collection by a licensed trash and garbage collection service as hereinafter described. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-38. - Accumulation of material treated as disposed. 
Where a party claims the accumulation of refuse, ashes, dust, or wastes from building operations is not a "disposal" within the section 17-37 meaning, the allowance of the accumulation for a period of more than seven days without removal will presumptively cause the accumulation to come within the meaning of section 17-37. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-39. - Screening of dumpsters. 
Business, commercial, educational, and other nonresidential buildings and any multifamily residential building for which the use of a commercial or multi-user dumpster has been authorized by the city shall screen any portion of a dumpster which is visible to an average person from a public street, parking lot, or residential building, which is within 300 feet of such dumpster or as provided in the city's zoning ordinance or development regulations, which ever is less. Said screening shall be constructed of building or fencing materials or shrubs, or evergreen trees that are of sufficient opacity to conceal the dumpster from view and such screening plan must be approved in writing by the public works director or his/her designee. Individual lots zoned under industrial classifications are exempt from the screening requirements, if the properties on each side and in front or across the street from the front of said lots are also zoned under industrial classifications. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-40. - Restaurant container. 
Restaurant containers shall be placed on a concrete pad or other nonabsorbent surface material, in accordance with the county health department requirements. Each restaurant shall have its own container or share a container with another restaurant, but shall not share a container with another type of business. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-41. - Certain matters not to be placed in containers. 
Dead animals, feces, explosives, dangerous and corrosive materials, clothing taken from persons with infectious diseases, heavy metals, bulky waste or any hazardous waste shall not be placed in any trash or garbage receptacle, cart or dumpster. Produce, meats, poultry, and food preparation oils shall be placed in sealed bags prior to being placed in any trash or garbage receptacle, cart or dumpster in such a manner as to minimize noxious or offensive odor emanating therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-42. - Doors and lids to be kept closed. 
Except when trash or garbage is being loaded into carts or dumpsters, or pickup of the same is being affected, all doors for screening, doors or lids of carts or dumpsters shall be kept closed. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-43. - Scavenging. 
No person other than the owner thereof shall interfere with any trash or garbage receptacle, cart or dumpster placed for the purpose of storing solid waste, or remove or take any of the contents thereof, or remove any trash or garbage receptacle, cart or dumpster from the location where the trash or garbage receptacle, cart or dumpster has been placed by the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-44. - Dumping and littering prohibited. 
(a)  All persons, firms, individuals, corporations or associations of individuals are hereby prohibited from dumping or discarding trash, refuse, bulky waste, rubbish, garbage, or discarded articles of all kinds, including but not limited to refrigerators, stoves, furniture, cans, bottles, boxes, sacks, waste paper, tires, batteries, hazardous waste, and all types of articles not suitable for human use, on private or public property in the corporate limits of the city, including streets, alleys sidewalks, highways, parks and recreational areas. 
(b)  Dumping of any of the items referenced in sub section (a) hereinabove by any person, firm, individual, corporation, or association (hereinafter "person") in a container not owned by such person or for which such person does not have permission shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-45. - Method of disposal. 
All waste and related materials described in section 17-44 shall be discarded in containers, transfer station, landfills and sanitary dumps. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-46. - Maintenance of carts. 
The city contractor shall provide one cart for each residential unit and commercial unit, as appropriate. The city contractor will replace (or at its option, repair) carts, which require replacement or repair as a result of normal wear and tear, and not as a result of misuse by the city resident. If the cart is deemed destroyed by the resident, then a charge of $60.00 will be applied to the resident's next quarterly bill. If the cart is deemed lost or stolen, then a charge of $30.00 will be applied to the residential unit or commercial unit's next quarterly bill. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-47. - Placement of carts. 
All moveable carts provided to residents shall be placed at the curbside location for pick-up not earlier than 12 hours prior to the scheduled collection date and shall be removed from such location within 24 hours of the collection date. No person shall leave the cart at the location for pick-up in excess of the time periods set forth herein; provided, however, that no person shall be cited for violating this section in the event that the regular collection schedule is interrupted. Carts shall not be placed in such a manner so as to block or obstruct mail receptacles, water meters or fire hydrants. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-48. - Penalty. 
Any person in violation of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be subject to prosecution and subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-14 of the Code of Ordinances for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Secs. 17-49—17-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SANITATION AND COLLECTION 

Sec. 17-56. - Collection by city contractor. 
All refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the city contractor. All refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed by the city contractor under the supervision of the public works director. The public works director shall have the authority to make regulations concerning the administration of this chapter as he/she finds necessary, and to change and modify the same after notice as required by law, provided that such regulations are not contrary to the provisions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-57. - Residential services; general conditions of residential collection. 
(a)  The city contractor for refuse collection and removal shall provide minimum once weekly curb service collection of refuse at residential units except as otherwise set out herein. 
(b)  The city or its authorized agent for refuse collection and removal shall provide collection of refuse for disabled persons, as defined in section 17-59 and as directed in that section. 
(c)  Owners or tenants of residential units shall place the refuse in the carts and the carts shall be placed, on assigned collection days, at front curbside locations in such manner as not to obstruct passage. Owners shall place the carts at appropriate curbside locations at or before 6:00 a.m. or prior to the arrival of the collection vehicles. This placement shall not be made before dusk on the date prior to collection day. Any refuse placed on the curb after departure of the pickup crew of the city or its authorized agent shall subject the owner to prosecution for violation of this chapter should the street become littered from refuse. 
(d)  Owners or tenants shall remove the carts from curbside location to storage location, which storage location shall be nearer to the residential unit located on the premises than to any street abutting the premises; removal of the cart should be accomplished within 24 hours following collection on the date the contents are emptied and collected. 
(e)  Owners or tenants shall prevent the continued, excessive and unsightly accumulation of refuse upon their property or the public thoroughfares bounding upon owner's property. 
(f)  It shall be a violation of this chapter to place or cause to be placed for collection any hazardous waste, any acid, explosive material, inflammable liquids or dangerous or corrosive material of any kind. 
(g)  Bulky waste may be collected at the curbside once every week. Owners shall be responsible for the removal of any CFCs and freon from any items of bulky waste prior to its collection. 
(h)  Refuse generated from the conduct of customary home occupations carried on from residential units will be collected on a residential fee basis. 
(i)  All refuse will be collected by the city contractor if placed in the cart. No open containers shall be permitted. 
(j)  Yard trimmings shall be collected by the city contractor once every week if placed at curbside for collection. A private contractor providing landscaping maintenance must remove yard trimmings from the premises and may not be placed at curbside for collection. 
(k)  Owners of a residential unit shall be responsible for the proper disposition of any dead animals. 
(l)  During any week in which there is an observed holiday or extremely harsh weather conditions, such as snow or ice, the city contractor may collect refuse in accordance with an altered collection schedule as needed. 
(m)  Nothing in this chapter shall prevent owners from contracting with the city contractor for additional services at additional costs. 
(n)  The city at all times reserves the right to direct and control all relevant aspects of the time, place and manner of residential refuse service. Nothing in this chapter is intended to abridge the city's right to ownership and control of the waste stream. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-58. - Residential disposal methods. 
Owners of record of all residential units shall obtain service for each such unit from the city contractor except for multi-family developments which have contracts with other outside contractors. Failure to provide evidence of proper disposal of refuse upon request by city officials (receipts, canceled checks, etc.) shall be a violation of this chapter, punishable as set forth in section 17-48. Refuse may not be disposed of by any person in an open dump nor may any person cause, suffer, allow or permit open dumping on his/her property. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-59. - Disabled. 
(a)  Any person who is a full-time resident of a residential unit and who is disabled to the extent that he or she is incapable of moving his/her refuse shall obtain a physician's certificate which states with particularity the nature and extent of such disability. Disabled persons shall not be required to place the refuse at curbside. This subsection shall not apply unless all of the adult persons in a residential unit are disabled and obtain such physician's certificate. Certificates will be mailed to the city contractor with a copy to the public works director. This subsection also applies to temporary disability not to exceed 90 days. The city's contractor may make reasonable rules for noncurbside collection for disabled persons; all garbage and refuse must be bagged. 
(b)  The city contractor or its authorized agent shall provide recycling services to disabled persons to the same extent such services may be provided under section 17-61. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-60. - Commercial collection. 
(a)  The owner of any commercial establishment shall be responsible for the collection and transportation of all refuse accumulated at such establishment to a refuse handling facility operating in compliance with state regulation and must arrange for service with the city or its authorized agent. No business license or renewal thereof shall be issued until the owner or occupant of such premises has arranged with the city contractor to provide refuse collection for that commercial establishment. 
(b)  The frequency of refuse collection from any commercial establishment shall be determined in accordance with its need and convenience as determined by the public works director. If necessary to protect public health, the public works director shall have the authority to require more frequent collections than originally determined. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided for herein, no other person, firm or corporation shall collect or convey over any of the streets or alleys of the city or dispose of any refuse accumulated in the city other than the city contractor. To the extent there exists, as of the date of the enactment of this chapter, a validly enforceable contract for refuse collection by and between any commercial establishment within the city and a third party company, not the authorized agent of the city, such contract will, upon application made by the commercial establishment who is a party to the contract, be allowed to expire, excluding any provisions for renewal, before the city shall require the commercial establishment to exclusively use the city contractor for refuse collection services. 
(d)  All commercial establishments or other entities producing hazardous waste or special waste shall be responsible for the disposal of and provide for the disposal of the hazardous waste or special waste in accordance with all federal and state laws and regulations. 
(e)  The owner of any commercial establishment serviced by dumpsters which property is adjacent to a residential area shall cause to be built, around the area in which the dumpster is located, a screened fence of durable quality and construction at least six feet in height which conceals and blocks the container from the view of any public property. The owner of any commercial establishment shall provide to the city or its authorized agent unimpeded access to each dumpster by the collection vehicles on collection days at collection times. No parking or other obstructions shall be permitted in the access area for dumpsters. 
(f)  Concrete pads of appropriate size and construction shall be provided for dumpsters or groups of dumpsters by the property owner. Adequate drainage shall be provided in and around the pad areas. 
(g)  As a condition to the issuance of a permit for the construction of a commercial establishment, arrangements for the storage of refuse and location of dumpsters must be approved by the public works director or his/her designee. 
(h)  Owners of commercial establishments shall be responsible for maintaining the area surrounding dumpsters clean and free of accumulation of refuse. 
(i)  The city reserves the right at all times to direct and control all relevant aspects of the time, place and manner of commercial refuse service. Nothing in this chapter is intended to abridge the city's right to ownership and control of the waste stream. 
(Ord. No. 03-28, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 17-61. - Recycling program. 
(a)  Owners of all residential units may participate in the city's recycling program. 
(b)  The city contractor shall collect at least once every week, pursuant to a contractor-provided list of guidelines, certain recyclable materials which may include corrugated cardboard boxes, newspapers, plastic (PET and HDPE), aluminum and tin cans. 
(c)  The city contractor may change the type and number of recyclable materials, and to re-determine collection and disposal of recyclable materials as viable alternatives are developed. 
(d)  The city contractor may provide one bin to each unit of a residential unit in which the residents shall deposit their recyclable materials. The cost of the bin shall be incorporated into the monthly charge for refuse collection services. The contractor may provide carts to condominiums or multi-family residential units to be placed in a common location where all residents of the condominium or multi-family residential unit may deposit their recyclable materials. The contractor may provide other appropriate recycling containers to customers as the need arises. 
(e)  Recyclable materials, which are placed in designated recycling bins for regular curbside collection, collected by the contractor shall become the property of the contractor. 
(f)  Owners of residential units shall place the recyclable materials in the bin and the bin shall be placed, on assigned collection days, at front curbside locations in such manner as not to obstruct passage. Owners shall place the bins at appropriate curbside location at or before 6:00 a.m. or prior to the arrival of the collection vehicles. This placement shall not be made before dusk on the day prior to collection day. Any recyclable materials placed on the curb after departure of the collection crew of the city contractor shall subject the owner to prosecution for violation of this ordinance should the street become littered from such recyclable materials.
