A speed limit of 25 miles per hour is hereby established for all streets within the city with the exception of those streets indicated in section 20-93 of this code with the further exception of areas of certain streets designated as "School Zones." Speed limits within "School Zones" are hereby established at 20 miles per hour during school hours. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, § I, 6-21-93) 
Sec. 20-93. - Speed limits on specific streets. 
(a)  Established. Pursuant to Georgia Code 40, Article 9, section 40-6-183, of the Uniform Rules of the Road Act, for local authorities to alter lawful speed limits, the following speed limits within the city are established: 
ON-SYSTEM  Signs to be Erected by Georgia Department of Transportation 

 
OFF-SYSTEM  Signs to be Erected by City of Newnan 

 
(b)  Violations. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided for by law. 
(Ord. No. 14-93, § II, 6-21-93; Ord. No. 95-24, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 96-23, 10-8-96; Ord. No. 00-15, § I, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 00-40, § 12-26-00; Ord. No. 04-03A, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 06-4, § I, 4-11-06; Ord. No. 12-6, § I(Exh. A), 5-22-12) 
Sec. 20-94. - Speed limit restrictions; construction sites. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the speed limits set forth in section 20-92 or section 20-93 herein, either the department of transportation or the city street superintendent are hereby authorized to establish a maximum speed limit through any construction site located on or adjacent to any street or highway within the city limits. 
(b)  Whenever speed zones are established pursuant to subsection (a) hereinabove by the department of transportation or the street superintendent, there shall be erected or posted a sign of adequate size at the beginning point of such speed zone designating the zone, the speed limit to be observed therein, and the minimum fine for exceeding such speed, and there shall be erected or posted at the end of such speed zone an adequate sign indicating the end of such speed zone, which sign shall also indicate such different speed limit as may then be observed. Where the speed limit established pursuant to subsection (a) hereinabove is at least ten miles per hour less than the established speed limit on the street or highway, there shall be erected at least 600 feet in advance of the beginning of the speed zone a sign of adequate size which shall bear the legend "Reduce Speed Ahead." 
(c)  A person convicted of exceeding the speed limit in any speed zone established pursuant to subsection (a) hereinabove shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature and shall be punished as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 95-22, § I, 9-26-95) 
Sec. 20-95. - Definitions. 
(a)  Truck/trailers: A motorized vehicle having ten wheels or more and/or tandem axles which generally has attached thereto a trailer for the purposes of hauling. 
(b)  Designated truck route: Specific streets authorized for truck/trailer traffic within the corporate limits of the city. Those streets or roads are designated as: 
(1)  Georgia Highway 34, from its intersection with Interstate 85 to its intersection with Georgia Highway 34 By-Pass; and 
(2)  U.S. Highway 29 North from its intersection with the city limits to its intersection with Georgia Highway 34 By-Pass; and 
(3)  Georgia Highway 34 By-Pass. 
(Ord. No. 99-09, § 1, 3-9-99) 
Sec. 20-96. - Prohibited truck trailer travel; exceptions; signage. 
(a)  Through truck trailers not stopping for pick up or deliveries in the city are prohibited from traveling along any streets within the city limits, except along the designated routes as set forth in this section. Truck/trailer deliveries or pick ups within the corporate boundaries of the city are permitted. 
(b)  The city clerk shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck routes and streets upon which truck traffic is permitted; the maps shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available to the public. 
(c)  The chief of police shall cause those streets upon which truck traffic is prohibited to be clearly sign-posted to give notice that section 20-96 is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 99-09, § 1, 3-9-99) 
Sec. 20-97. - Violation. 
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable pursuant to the provisions of section 1-14 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-09, § 1, 3-9-99) 
Secs. 20-98—20-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Standing or parking vehicles containing livestock, § 4-8. 

Sec. 20-111. - Establishment of parking restrictions in designated areas. 
(a)  Placement of signs. When an ordinance or regulation of the city so provides, the city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall designate those streets or parts of streets in the city upon which parking shall be prohibited, or parking time limits established, or parking is otherwise restricted, and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When such signs are erected and in place, it shall be unlawful for any person to disobey the directions of such signs. 
(Code 1972, § 15-74; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-112. - Signs required to regulate parking. 
Whenever by the provisions of this chapter or any other regulation of the city any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited or restricted on designated streets or parts of streets, it shall be the duty of the city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1972, § 15-75; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-113. - Parking parallel, on right-hand of street unless otherwise indicated; exception for one-way streets. 
Except where otherwise indicated by appropriate signs, markings or other devices, all parking in the city shall be parallel to the curb, and along the right-hand side of the street facing in the direction of travel; provided, however, that upon one-way streets, vehicles may park along the left-hand side of the street facing in the direction of travel, unless such parking is otherwise prohibited. 
(Code 1972, § 15-76) 
Sec. 20-114. - Engine to be stopped, brakes set when vehicle is parked. 
The person in charge of a motor vehicle shall not park the same upon a street with the engine running, but in departing therefrom shall stop such engine and set the brakes. 
(Code 1972, § 15-77) 
Sec. 20-115. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
No motor vehicle shall be left standing on the streets of the city between sunset and sunrise unless there is displayed from the front and rear thereof appropriate illuminating devices. 
(Code 1972, § 15-78) 
Sec. 20-116. - Parking on sidewalk, prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked on any sidewalk in the city any automobile, truck or motor vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 15-80) 
Sec. 20-117. - Parking between curb and sidewalk adjacent to street, prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked in that area between the curb and the sidewalk adjacent to any street in the city any automobile, truck or other motor vehicle. 
(Code 1972, § 15-79) 
Sec. 20-118. - Parking restrictions; first fire district; city property; other restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked, any automobile or motor vehicle on a public street within the first fire district of the city for more than 24 hours in any one place. Except as provided in subsection (b), it shall also be unlawful for any person to so park any automobile or motor vehicle on a public street outside the first fire district of the city for more than 72 hours in any one place. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked, any automobile or motor vehicle on city property or within a city parking lot for more than 24 hours. This restriction shall not apply to city-owned vehicles. 
(c)  No motorized vehicle in excess of 7,000 pounds (empty weight), trailer, boat, vehicle not in operating condition or currently licensed, vehicle with more than four wheels or a total number of vehicles in excess of four as set forth in the zoning ordinance shall be permitted to be parked in front of or at the side of the main dwelling on a lot in a residential area or neighborhood, unless same is parked or stored completely within an enclosed garage or roofed carport. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the limitation set forth in paragraph (a) of this section, no motorized vehicle in excess of 7,000 pounds (empty weight) or trailer, boat or vehicle with more than four wheels shall be permitted to be parked or left standing along any street or roadway in any residential zoned area or neighborhood. The provisions of this subparagraph (c) shall not apply to vehicles making deliveries of goods or merchandise to residents or businesses located in such residential zoned area or neighborhood or to vehicles temporarily parked for the purpose of loading or unloading household or business goods and furnishings (moving van type vehicles). 
(Code 1972, § 15-81; Ord. No. 96-14, 7-9-96; Ord. No. 99-06, § 1, 1-12-99) 
Sec. 20-119. - Fire lanes, police and handicapped parking zones; designated, use restricted. 
(a)  Unless expressly authorized, by permit or otherwise, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city where the curbing is marked by yellow lines. Excepted from the terms of this section are properly marked or licensed emergency or law enforcement vehicles. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city designated and marked as a fire or emergency lane, access or alleyway. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city designated as a handicapped zone unless identification as a handicapped vehicle is properly displayed. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city designated 15-minute zone for any time exceeding 15-minutes. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle of any kind within any area in the city designated commercial loading zoning unless actively loading or unloading and in no event for any time exceeding one hour. 
(Code 1972, § 15-82; Ord. No. 14-92, 5-11-92; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-120. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
(a)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall erect signs prohibiting parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property when it has been determined such parking would interfere with traffic or create a hazardous condition. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When official signs are erected prohibiting parking upon that side of a street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(c)  Prohibited parking. It shall be unlawful for any person to park on Water Works Road and Sewell Road where such roads adjoin the premises of Newnan High School on any school day between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. It shall further be unlawful for any person to park on LaGrange Street and Armory Road, where such street or road adjoins the premises of Newnan High School between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on any school day. Excepted from these restrictions are students, teachers and administrators attending Newnan High School and persons having legitimate business to transact at Newnan High School. 
(Code 1972, § 15-83; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-121. - Parking on narrow streets. 
(a)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall erect signs prohibiting parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not permit free and unobstructed passage of vehicles. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1972, § 15-84; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-122. - Parking, standing on one-way roadways. 
(a)  Signs required. If a roadway includes two or more separate lanes and traffic is restricted to the same one-way direction upon each lane of any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left-hand side of such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. 
(b)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the left-hand side of any such one-way roadway and shall erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 15-85; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-123. - Hazardous or congested places. 
(a)  Placement of signs. The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall designate by proper signs placed in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b)  Effect of signs. When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized in this section no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1972, § 15-86; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-124. - Designation of curb loading zones. 
The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones. hereinafter in this chapter referred to as commercial loading zones, and shall place and maintain appropriate signs or other devices indicating the same and stating the hours during which the restrictions thereof shall apply. 
(Code 1972, § 15-87; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-125. - Bus zones; designation, use restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle except a bus within those areas where the curbing is marked by yellow lines and where there is a sign denoting the same as a parking space for buses, such areas being reserved for the use of buses only. 
(Code 1972, § 15-88) 
Sec. 20-126. - Taxicab zones; designation, use restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle except a taxicab within those areas where the curbing is marked by yellow lines and where there is a sign denoting the same as a parking space for taxicabs only, such areas being reserved for the use of taxicabs only. 
(Code 1972, § 15-89) 
Sec. 20-127. - Taxicab parking regulated. 
(a)  Use of zones is exclusive. The taxicab companies of the city shall have the exclusive privilege of parking taxicabs in the spaces marked for such purposes. 
(b)  Manner of parking. Taxicabs must and shall park in the space at the points marked off for such taxicabs and must be parked within the lines so marked. 
(c)  Privilege is revocable. The privilege to park in the designated spaces is permissive only and can be revoked at any time by the mayor and city council. 
(d)  Prohibited parking. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any taxicab to park a taxicab at any place except the spaces designated for taxicabs. 
(Code 1972, § 15-90) 
Sec. 20-128. - Parking permits. 
No permits for parking in the city shall be issued except to the county commissioners for their use while on official business and disabled persons holding doctor's certificates attesting to such disability. 
(Code 1972, § 15-91) 
Sec. 20-129. - Parking, making deliveries by certain vehicles restricted in first fire district. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked on any street within the first fire district of the city a truck and trailer or a trailer exceeding an overall length of 26 feet, for a period of more than one hour at a time in any one place. 
(b)  It shall further be unlawful to make more than one daily delivery to more than one business establishment or to daily pick up or receive goods, wares or merchandise from more than one business establishment with a tractor-trailer within the first fire district of the city between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked on any street outside the first fire district of the city a truck and trailer or a trailer exceeding an overall length of 26 feet, for a period of more than 12 hours at a time or overnight. 
(Code 1972, § 15-92; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-130. - Enforcement of parking regulations. 
(a)  Scope of section. Any and all vehicles parked on any public street or alley in the city shall at all times be subject to the supervision and control of the police force of the city and any officer thereof. This section shall also apply to parking of vehicles in an area where the curbing is marked by yellow lines, in an area designated as fire or emergency lane or in an area designated as a handicapped zone. 
(b)  Duty of enforcement. It shall be the duty of every member of the police department of the city and/or employee clothed with police powers to exercise supervision and control over vehicles parked on the public streets or alleys in the city and to prohibit as far as possible parking that obstructs such streets or alleys. This duty shall apply to enforcement of the parking restrictions set forth in section 20-119; in addition, the chief of police and the fire inspector shall have the duty and authority to issue citations for violations of the restrictions set forth therein. Reasonable discretion shall be exercised in the enforcement of this section. 
(c)  Obedience required. Every person who parks a vehicle on any public street or alley in the city shall park the vehicle subject to the supervision and control of the policeman and/or employees with police power in the city, and every such person shall, when requested or directed by any member of the police department and/or employee clothed with police powers, immediately move his automobile and park it in such place as shall be designated, or if a parking place is not designated to remove it from where it is parked at the time such owner is requested or directed to do so. 
(d)  Violations. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to move any vehicle parked in the city on streets or alleys after requested or directed to move the vehicle by any member of the police department and/or any employee clothed with police powers. 
(Code 1972, § 15-93) 
Sec. 20-131. - Vehicle owner not to cause or permit parking violations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to countenance, cause, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stop, stand or park upon any of the public streets or public places in the city in violation of the provisions of this chapter. However, in no case shall two persons be penalized for any one parking violation. 
(Code 1972, § 15-94; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-132. - Penalty for parking violations. 
(a)  The charge for violation of a 15-minute parking restriction in any designated parking area shall be established by resolution of city council. If the violation is unpaid within seven days, the fine shall be doubled. 
(b)  The charge for violation of a designated handicapped parking space shall be established by resolution of city council. If the violation is unpaid within seven days, the fine shall be doubled. 
(c)  The charge for violation of a designated commercial loading zone shall be established by resolution of city council. If the violation is unpaid within seven days, the fine shall be doubled. 
(d)  Habitual offenders of parking regulations shall be assessed an additional charge as established by city council. Habitual offense shall be defined as conviction of five or more violations of section 20-134 or 20-135 within a calendar year. The habitual offender charge shall be assessed to violators on the fifth and each subsequent violation during the calendar year. 
(e)  If the fine is not paid within 30 days from the date of issuance, a warrant shall be issued for such person commanding such person to appear before the city recorder, and such person, if found guilty of willfully failing to pay the ticket within the prescribed time limit, shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in section 1-14 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 15-95; Ord. No. 02-92, 1-6-92; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-133. - Towing away of certain illegally parked vehicles. 
Subject to state law requirements, the police chief is hereby authorized to tow away and store any vehicle parked in any of the following situations: 
(1)  In a 15-minute zone illegally for more than 30 minutes. 
(2)  In a commercial loading zone illegally for more than one hour. 
(3)  In a designated handicapped space without proper authorization. 
(4)  In the first fire district for more than 24 hours. 
(5)  Outside the first fire district within the city for more than 72 hours. 
(Code 1972, § 15-96; Ord. No. 20-90, 8-6-90; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-134. - Restricted parking in central business district. 
(a)  The city engineer, as traffic engineer, in consultation with the chief of police shall have the authority to determine the location of restricted parking within the city limits. Parking restrictions shall be placed to optimize the use of parking facilities while maintaining adequate traffic flow and safety. 
(b)  The following types of restricted parking shall be allowed: 
(1)  Fifteen-minute zones; 
(2)  Commercial loading zones; 
(3)  Handicapped spaces. 
(Code 1972, § 15-97; Ord. No. 13-89, 4-10-89; Ord. No. 21-90, 8-6-90; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-135. - No parking areas. 
(a)  Temple Avenue. No parking is permitted on Temple Avenue within the corporate limits of the city as described as follows: 
Beginning at a point 1,065 feet (0.2 mile) east of mile post 8, south side of State Route 16 (Temple Avenue), which point is the west boundary line of Bank of Coweta, point marked by curb delineating west driveway of Bank; thence 159 feet east of point of beginning to east property line of Bank of Coweta; also, north side of State Route 16, between points directly opposite the points described above. 
(b)  Greenville Street. No parking is permitted on Greenville Street (SR 14) at M.P. 14.10 to 14.12, within the city as described as follows: 
State Route 14, 16. Begin no parking on the east side of State Route 14 at M.P. 14.10 and continue to the north for a distance of 110 feet, M.P. 14.12. 
(c)  State Route 14 (US 29, Jackson Street). No parking is allowed any time on State Route 14 (US 29, Jackson Street), west side only, as follows: 
Beginning at a point 75 feet north of Wesley Street (M.P. 0.25) and continuing south to Wesley Street (M.P. 0.26), a distance of 0.01 mile. 
(d)  State Route 14 (US 29, Jackson Street). No parking is allowed anytime on State Route 14 (US 29, Jackson Street) east side only, as follows: 
Beginning at a point 75 feet north of Wesley Street (M.P. 0.25) and continuing south to Wesley Street (M.P. 0.26), a distance of 0.01 mile. 
(Code 1972, § 15-98) 
Sec. 20-136. - Use of parking spaces when doing work at building. 
Persons doing temporary construction work at a building in the city and using trucks or other vehicles therefore, and desiring to occupy a parking space without being required to move the vehicles each two hours may apply for and obtain a parking permit, the same to be issued upon payment of a fee set forth in the city's schedule of fees per space to be occupied by the applicant for permit. Such permit shall allow the permit holder to occupy the number of spaces designated in the permit without regard to 24 hour and 72 hours limitations set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 15-99; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 20-137. - Handicapped parking—Law adopted. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 20-1 of this Code and pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-220 through 40-6-227, such sections of state law are hereby incorporated in this section by reference as and for the handicapped parking laws of this city with the like effect as if recited in this section. 
(b)  The sign designations for handicapped parking places shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 40-6-221. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the failure of the property owner to properly mark and sign handicap parking places in accordance with law, it shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park any motor vehicle in any area on public or private property which has been clearly designated and reserved for use by handicapped persons in vehicles displaying a valid handicapped parking permit, unless such vehicle clearly displays a valid unexpired handicapped parking permit or unless there is attached to the vehicle a specifically designated license plate for disabled veterans or other disabled persons authorized under O.C.G.A. § 40-6-222(d). 
(Ord. No. 20-92, § 15-101, 8-24-92) 
Sec. 20-138. - Same—Enforcement. 
(a)  In addition to the enforcement authority set forth in section 20-130, the chief of police, or his designee, shall have the authority to appoint any person who is a citizen of the United States, is of good moral character, has not been previously convicted of a felony, and is a handicapped person as defined under state law, to enforce the provisions of the handicapped parking laws of the city. 
(b)  Each person appointed pursuant to this section shall complete an application, satisfactorily complete a course of training on handicapped parking enforcement, and take and subscribe an oath of office as prescribed by the appointing authority. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the application, the chief of police or his designee shall cause a complete and thorough investigation to be made of the applicant to determine his moral, physical and mental qualifications. 
(d)  Any person appointed under this section and sworn shall have the power to serve citations for violations for failure to comply with the handicapped parking laws of this city, in the manner as any law enforcement officer of the city, subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  No person so appointed shall be deemed a peace officer, nor have the general powers of a police officer, nor an employee of the city, nor receive any compensation therefrom. 
(2)  No person appointed shall be required to complete training or be certified as a peace officer. 
(3)  No person appointed shall have the power or duty to enforce any other traffic or criminal laws. 
(4)  No person appointed shall have the power to possess and carry firearms and other weapons for the purpose of enforcing the handicapped parking laws. 
(5)  No person appointed shall be entitled to any indemnification from the city for any injury or property damage sustained as a result of enforcement activities. Each authorized person shall specifically acknowledge that such person has no rights to any claim of injury or property damage resulting from handicap enforcement activities. 
(6)  The city shall not be liable or accountable for or on account of any act or omission of any person appointed pursuant to this section in connection with such person's enforcement of the handicapped parking laws. Each authorized person shall specifically hold harmless the city, its employees and agents, from liability for any such act or omission by such authorized person. 
(e)  Every person appointed under this section shall be required to wear a lapel badge for identification purposes while in the performance of his duty. 
(Ord. No. 20-92, § 15-102, 8-24-92) 
Secs. 20-139—20-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RAILROADS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Railroad companies, O.C.G.A. § 46-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 20-156. - Maintenance of crossings, bridges, trestles. 
It shall be the duty of all railroad companies entering the city to make, keep and maintain good and suitable crossings at all streets where their roadbeds cross; and they shall also keep and maintain all bridges and trestles in good and secure condition. 
(Code 1972, § 22-1) 
Sec. 20-157. - Notice of needed construction, repair. 
In all cases in which a railroad company is required or liable by law to build bridges in the city or to keep bridges or crossings in the city in repair, on or across a street crossed by the tracks of such railroad company when the building of a new bridge, or the repair of the bridge already built is declared by the city council to be necessary or proper, railroad company shall be notified by the city council to commence the building or repair of such bridge within ten days and to prosecute the same in good faith to completion. 
(Code 1972, § 22-2) 
Sec. 20-158. - Service, contents of notice to construct, repair. 
The notice provided for in section 20-157 shall be in writing, and shall be served by any policeman of the city, or the principal officer of such railroad company in the city, or by leaving the same at the principal office of the company in the city. Such notice shall contain a general plan or character of the bridge to be built or repaired and material of the same, or a description of the work to be done at a crossing, and also where the bridge to be built or repaired, or the crossing to be improved, is located. 
(Code 1972, § 22-3) 
Sec. 20-159. - Construction, repair by city in lieu of railroad. 
(a)  Authority. Should any railroad company fail or refuse to commence in good faith the building or repairing of a bridge or the repairing of a crossing within the time specified in the notice provided for in section 20-157 and in accordance with the provisions of sections 20-156, 20-157 and 20-158, or to notify the city of a refusal to comply with the notice served, then and in that event the city will proceed to do such work of building or repairing such bridge or crossing at the charge of such railroad company. 
(b)  Collection of cost. Within five days after the completion of such work the street superintendent shall report under oath in writing to the city clerk the amount and value of the services performed or expense incurred in such work, whereupon the clerk shall issue execution for the amount of such value or expense against such defaulting railroad company, to which execution a defense may be made and filed, on oath to the city council and heard by the city council on ten days' notice to such railroad company by the city, such notice to be in writing and served in the manner prescribed in section 20-158. If the issue of the illegality be found against the company filing the same, then the execution shall proceed, and shall be levied on any property of such company in the city and after advertising, as in cases of land sold for taxes, the same may be sold to satisfy the execution. 
(Code 1972, § 22-4) 
Sec. 20-160. - Failure to maintain bridges, crossings. 
It shall be unlawful for any railroad company whose road crosses any streets in the city, to fail, neglect or refuse to have suitable crossings erected and kept in good repair at the different points on such roads where they cross the streets and public roads; or for any railroad company to refuse, neglect or fail to put in good order, all roads turned for the benefit of such railroad, or for any railroad company to neglect or refuse to build and keep in good repair, bridges of a proper width across their respective roads rendered necessary by excavation in building such road across the city streets. 
(Code 1972, § 22-5) 
Sec. 20-161. - Obstructions at railroad crossings. 
The several railroad companies whose roads are in the city shall not allow any street to be obstructed by any cars or other things left at any of the crossings, and if it shall become necessary in loading or unloading freight to stop longer than five minutes, it shall be the duty of the conductor of such train of cars to uncouple his cars at the point of crossing to allow vehicles to pass without unnecessary delay or inconvenience. 
(Code 1972, § 22-6) 
Sec. 20-162. - Laying, repairing railroad track. 
(a)  Application to do work. Any railroad company that may desire to lay any railroad track, or to repair any track already laid with the city, shall, before doing so, present in writing to the city council an application to do such work, which application shall show the location of the proposed track or the proposed work to be done on the track already laid. The city council may authorize, modify or reject and refuse such application as may in their judgment be for the best interest of the public. 
(b)  Restoration of street and sidewalk. Any company to whom permission is given to do such work shall restore the sidewalk or street where any such work is done to the same condition that existed before such work was done, and in repairing any such street or sidewalk shall use material similar to that already installed. 
(c)  Violations. It shall be unlawful for any person to do any work, either by excavating earth or by laying crossties, stringers or rails, or to remove cross ties, for the purpose of laying or repairing railroad tracks, within the city without first making application to and obtaining the consent of the city council thereto. 
(Code 1972, § 22-7) 
Sec. 20-163. - Report of additional track laid. 
It shall be the duty of each railroad company owning or operating trains in and through the city, to report the number of additional feet of track laid in the city, to the city clerk within ten days from the time that the work of laying additional track is completed. 
(Code 1972, § 22-8) 
Sec. 20-164. - Locomotive, railroad cars; maximum speed prescribed. 
It shall be unlawful to operate or cause to be operated any locomotive or railroad car within the city, at a greater rate of speed than 25 miles per hour. The provisions hereof shall apply both to the railroad company and to the employee of such company in charge of such locomotive or railroad car. 
(Code 1972, § 22-9) 
Sec. 20-165. - Blowing whistles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating a locomotive engine to blow the whistle thereof within the city, except in cases of emergency to prevent injury to persons or property. 
(Code 1972, § 22-10) 
Sec. 20-166. - Flagmen at designated crossings. 
(a)  Duty of railroad. At those railroad crossings in the city not equipped with mechanical devices to indicate the approach of a train, it shall be the duty of the railroad company responsible for such crossing to place a flagman on duty at such crossing, between the hours from 6:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. each day. 
(b)  Duty of flagman. It shall be the duty of the flagman during such hours to flag such crossing at the approach of any railroad car or locomotive so that persons attempting to cross such tracks at such point will be warned of the approaching railroad car or locomotive. 
(c)  Police authority of flagman. The flagman while on duty shall be vested with all the authority of a police officer of the city and upon being employed shall appear before the mayor and take and subscribe the oath of a police officer. 
(Code 1972, § 22-11) 
Chapter 21 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

Laws 1978, p. 2347, which provides that the board of water, sewerage and light commission is not empowered to discontinue utility services to the city or change the city any fee therefor, nor empowers the board to take title to and hold real property in its own name, or to set salaries of the persons serving as commissioners on the board, shall not be repealed or deleted on July 1, 1987, as a part of the State Constitution, but are specifically continued in force and effect on and after that date as a part of the State Constitution.
