e.  The SSN provided is the same as one submitted by other applicants or customers. 
f.  The address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar to the address or telephone number submitted by an unusually large number of applicants or customers. 
g.  The applicant or customer fails to provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in response to notification that the application is incomplete. 
h.  Personal identifying information is not consistent with personal identifying information that is on file with the creditor. 
i.  The applicant or customer cannot provide authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from a wallet or consumer report. 
(4)  Unusual use of or suspicious activity relating to a covered account. Examples of suspicious activity include: 
a.  Shortly following the notice of a change of address for an account, the city receives a request for the addition of authorized users on the account. 
b.  An account is used in a manner that is not consistent with established patterns of activity on the account. There is, for example: 
1.  Nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed payments; 
2.  A material change in the pattern of use of provided city services; 
c.  Mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as undeliverable although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with the customer's account. 
d.  The city is notified that the customer is not receiving paper account statements. 
e.  The city is notified of unauthorized charges or transactions in connection with a customer's account. 
f.  The city is notified by a customer, law enforcement or another person that it has opened a fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft. 
(5)  Notice from customers, law enforcement, victims or other reliable sources regarding possible identity theft or phishing relating to covered accounts. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 1, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-209. - Prevention and mitigation of identity theft. 
(a)  In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in restoring an existing covered account, handling an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect to existing covered accounts, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the director of finance who will notify the city manager or assistant to the city manager. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the director of finance who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the director of finance in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the director of finance: 
(1)  Contact the customer; 
(2)  Make the following changes to the account if it is apparent that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's covered account: 
a.  change any account numbers, passwords, security codes, or other security devices that permit access to an account; or 
b.  close the account. 
(3)  Cease attempts to collect additional charges from the customer and decline to sell the customer's account to a debt collector in the event that the customer's account has been accessed without authorization and such access has caused additional charges to accrue; 
(4)  Notify law enforcement, in the event that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's account causing additional charges to accrue or accessing personal identifying information; or 
(5)  Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. 
(b)  In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect an application for a new account, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the director of finance who will notify the city manager or assistant to the city manager. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the director of finance, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the director of finance in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the director of finance: 
(1)  Request additional identifying information from the applicant; 
(2)  Deny the application for the new account; 
(3)  Notify law enforcement of possible identity theft; or 
(4)  Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 1, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-210. - Updating the program. 
The city council shall annually review and, as recommended by the staff and deemed necessary by the commission, update the identity theft prevention program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the city and its covered accounts from identity theft. In so doing, the city council shall consider the following factors and exercise its discretion in amending the program: 
(1)  The city's experiences with identity theft; 
(2)  Updates in methods of identity theft; 
(3)  Updates in customary methods used to detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft; 
(4)  Updates in the types of accounts that the city offers or maintains; and 
(5)  Updates in service provider arrangements. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 1, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-211. - Program administration. 
The director of finance is responsible for oversight of the program and for program implementation. The city manager is responsible for reviewing reports prepared by staff regarding compliance with red flag requirements and with recommending material changes to the program, as necessary in the opinion of the city manager, to address changing identity theft risks and to identify new or discontinued covered types of covered accounts. Any recommended material changes to the program shall be submitted to the city council for consideration by the council. 
(1)  The director of finance will report to the city manager at least annually on compliance with the red flag requirements. The report will address material matters related to the program and evaluate issues such as: 
a.  The effectiveness of the policies and procedures of city in addressing the risk of identity theft in connection with the opening of covered accounts and with respect to existing covered accounts; 
b.  Service provider arrangements; 
c.  Significant incidents involving identity theft and management's response; and 
d.  Recommendations for material changes to the program. 
(2)  The director of finance and his or her direct supervisor are responsible for providing training to all employees responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account with respect to the implementation and requirements of the identity theft prevention program. The director of finance shall exercise his or her discretion in determining the amount and substance of training necessary. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 1, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-212. - Outside service providers. 
In the event that the city engages a service provider to perform an activity in connection with one or more covered accounts, the director of finance, the city manager and the city attorney shall exercise their discretion in reviewing such arrangements in order to ensure, to the best of their ability, that the service provider's activities are conducted in accordance with policies and procedures agreed upon by contract which are designed to detect any red flags that may arise in the performance of the service provider's activities and take appropriate steps to prevent or mitigate identity theft. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 1, 10-28-08) 
Secs. 21-213—21-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TREATMENT OF ADDRESS DISCREPANCIES 

Sec. 21-226. - Short title. 
[This article shall be known and may be cited as the] "Treatment of Address Discrepancies." 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 2, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-227. - Purpose. 
Pursuant to 16 CFR § 681.1, the purpose of this article is to establish a process by which the city will be able to form a reasonable belief that a consumer report relates to the consumer about whom it has requested a consumer credit report when the city has received a notice of address discrepancy. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 2, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-228. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, the following definitions apply: 
City means City of Newnan, Georgia. 
Commission means the Newnan Waters, Sewerage and Light Commission of the City of Newnan, Georgia. 
Notice of address discrepancy means a notice sent to a user by a consumer reporting agency pursuant to 15 U.S.C. § 1681(c)(h)(1), that informs the user of a substantial difference between the address for the consumer that the user provided to request the consumer report and the address(es) in the agency's file for the consumer. 2 [] 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 2, 10-28-08) 
Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
See 16 CFR § 681.1(b). 

Sec. 21-229. - Policy. 
In the event that the city receives a notice of address discrepancy, the city employee responsible for verifying consumer addresses for the purpose of providing the municipal service or account sought by the consumer shall perform one or more of the following activities, as determined to be appropriate by such employee: 
(1)  Compare the information in the consumer report with: 
a.  Information the city obtains and uses to verify a consumer's identity in accordance with the requirements of the customer information program rules implementing 31 U.S.C. § 5318(1); 
b.  Information the city maintains in its own records, such as applications for service, change of address notices, other customer account records or tax records; or 
c.  Information the city obtains from third-party sources that are deemed reliable by the relevant city employee; or 
(2)  Verify the information in the consumer report with the consumer. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 2, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-230. - Furnishing consumer's address to consumer reporting agency. 
(a)  In the event that the city reasonably confirms that an address provided by a consumer to the city is accurate, the city is required to provide such address to the consumer reporting agency from which the city received a notice of address discrepancy with respect to such consumer. This information is required to be provided to the consumer reporting agency when: 
(1)  The city is able to form a reasonable belief that the consumer report relates to the consumer about whom the city requested the report; 
(2)  The city establishes a continuing relation with the consumer; and 
(3)  The city regularly and in the ordinary course of business provides information to the consumer reporting agency from which it received the notice of address discrepancy. 
(b)  Such information shall be provided to the consumer reporting agency as part of the information regularly provided by the city to such agency for the reporting period in which the city establishes a relationship with the customer. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 2, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-231. - Methods of confirming consumer addresses. 
The city employee charged with confirming consumer addresses may, in his or her discretion, confirm the accuracy of an address through one or more of the following methods: 
(1)  Verifying the address with the consumer; 
(2)  Reviewing the city's records to verify the consumer's address; 
(3)  Verifying the address through third party sources; or 
(4)  Using other reasonable processes. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 2, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-232. - Designee. 
(a)  The city manager, in the absence of an assistant to the city manager, may designate another employee of the city to fulfill the city manager's duties under the city's identity theft prevention program; 
(b)  The director of finance may designate another employee of the finance department to fulfill the director of finance's duties under the city's theft prevention program. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 2, 10-28-08) 
Secs. 21-233—21-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - APPLICABILITY TO NEWNAN WATER, SEWERAGE AND LIGHT COMMISSION 

Sec. 21-251. - Short title. 
[This article shall be known and may be cited as the] "Applicability to Newnan Water, Sewerage and Light Commission." 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 3, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-252. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to extend the applicability of the Newnan Water, Sewerage and Light Commission to authorize the Newnan Water, Sewerage and Light Commission to adopt an identity theft prevention program not inconsistent with the city's identity theft prevention program or 16 CFR § 681.1. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 3, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-253. - Definitions. 
City means City of Newnan, Georgia 
Commission means the Newnan Water, Sewerage and Light Commission of the City of Newnan, Georgia 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 3, 10-28-08) 
Sec. 21-254. - Applicability. 
The requirements of the city's identity theft prevention program is hereby extended to the commission and the commission is hereby authorized to adopt an identity theft prevention program, not inconsistent with the city's identity theft prevention program or 16 CFR§681.1. 
(Ord. No. 08-16, § 3, 10-28-08) 
Chapter 22 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Certificates required. 
No person shall operate or permit a taxicab or any other automobile owned or controlled by him to be operated as a vehicle for hire in the city without having first obtained a certificate from the city council authorizing such operation. 
(Code 1972, § 27-1; Ord. No. 03-06, § 1, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 22-2. - Place of business required. 
No taxicab or any other automobile for hire shall operate in the city unless the owner thereof shall maintain a place of business from a building located on property within a commercially zoned district in which vehicles for hire is a permitted use in accordance with the most recently adopted zoning map and have first obtained certification of compliance from the city zoning administrator. 
(Code 1972, § 27-2; Ord. No. 96-6, § I, 3-13-96; Ord. No. 99-22, § 1, 11-23-99; Ord. No. 01-19, § I, 3-27-01; Ord. No. 03-06, § II, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 22-3. - Operation of vehicles for hire. 
No person shall operate a taxicab or any other vehicle for hire unless such person possesses the proper driver's license as required under the laws of the state and is not less than 18 years of age and has obtained a permit as set forth herein. 
(Code 1972, § 27-4; Ord. No. 03-06, § III, 3-11-03) 
Secs. 22-4—22-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-21. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicant means an individual registering a business authorized herein. 
Application means a form supplied by the city for the purpose of registering a business authorized herein. 
Business means the business of operating or owning a taxicab business. 
Certificate means certificate issued or approved by the city council authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a taxicab business within the city. 
City means City of Newnan, Georgia. 
Closely held corporation means a corporation not traded or listed on any stock exchange and which has fewer than 25 shareholders. 
Convicted or conviction shall include a plea of nolo contendere. 
Driver, operator means any person in charge of or driving or operating a taxicab, as defined herein, whether as owner, agent, employee or otherwise. 
Driver's permit means the permission granted by the governing body to a person to drive a taxicab within the city. 
Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form IRS W-2 but not a form IRS 1099. 
Highway means any of the public streets, alleys, lanes, boulevards, avenues, drives, circles, or roads of the city. 
Individual means a natural person. 
Interest in a business means an interest held by an owner or co-owner of a registered business; by a partner of a general or limited partnership which owns or co-owns a registered business; a stockholder of five percent or more shares in any closely held corporation which owns or co-owns a registered business; or anyone sharing in the income or corpus of any trust or estate having such an interest; or a person having subscriptions, options, and/or warranty for purchase of five percent or more of a closely held corporation's stock or 50 percent or more of any corporation's stock. 
Memorandum certificate means the card issued to a taxicab owner to display within the taxicab indicating that such taxicab has been issued a certificate. 
Owner means a person having an interest in a business, including a stockholder and to whom a certificate for operating a taxicab has been or is to be issued. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business, trust, receiver, fiduciary or other group or combination acting as a unit, body politic or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi-public, or any entity. 
Taxicab means any motor vehicle seating six or fewer persons and the driver, operating upon any street on call or demand, accepting or soliciting passengers indiscriminately for hire between such points along such streets as may be directed by the passengers being so transported. 
Traffic officer means the chief of police or the officer the chief has designated to hold responsibilities as set forth in this article. 
Vehicles for hire means taxicab as defined herein or limousine as defined in section 22-101. 
(Code 1972, § 27-19; Ord. No. 03-06, § IV, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 22-22. - Compliance with laws, due regard for safety required. 
All taxicabs operating within the city shall comply with all laws of the United States of America, the state and the city regulating the speed, the operation of motor vehicles and the requirements for safety equipment and devices. All passengers, whether adult, children or infants shall use the required passenger restraint devices including child restraints as necessary. Drivers shall show due regard for the safety, comfort and convenience of passengers, for the safe and careful transportation of property and for the safety of the general public. 
(Code 1972, § 27-33) 
Sec. 22-23. - Identification of vehicles as taxicabs. 
(a)  Information required. All motor vehicles operated as taxicabs in the city shall be marked on the outside with the following information with respect thereto: 
(1)  The name of the owner of the taxicab. 
(2)  The word "taxicab" or "taxi." 
(3)  If a fleet of more than one taxicab is operated by one company or owner, a number shall be assigned to each vehicle, prominently displayed and identifying. 
(4)  Any other information which may be deemed necessary to identify such vehicle as required by the traffic officer. 
(b)  Affixing information. The above markings or identification shall be prominently displayed on both sides of the vehicles operated as taxicabs in letters of not less than three inches in height and must be printed so that the identification may be easily read at a distance of at least 50 feet. Such information may be displayed on vehicle with paint, by stencil, by decals or with magnetic signs. 
(Code 1972, § 27-34) 
Sec. 22-24. - Riding on exterior of vehicle. 
No person shall be permitted to ride on the fender, hood, roof or any other exterior portion of a taxicab. 
(Code 1972, § 27-55) 
Sec. 22-25. - Refusal to pay fare. 
Any person using a taxicab in the city without paying the amount of fare or charges requested by the taxicab driver, within the limits prescribed in this article, shall be guilty of violation of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 27-59) 
Secs. 22-26—22-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATION OF BUSINESS 

Sec. 22-41. - Certificate—Application. 
All persons applying for a certificate provided for in section 22-1 shall do so in writing to the traffic officer on the form provided by him. Such applicant shall furnish all information required by such form in complete detail and shall certify under oath to the correctness of the information. 
(Code 1972, § 27-20; Ord. No. 03-06, § V, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 22-42. - Same—Action upon application. 
The traffic officer shall investigate the application provided for in section 22-41 and shall make a recommendation to the city council on whether such applicant should be granted a certificate. 
(Code 1972, § 27-21; Ord. No. 03-06, § VI, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 22-43. - Same—Issuance. 
After receiving approval of the application provided for in section 22-42 from the city council, the certificate shall be issued by the city clerk upon payment of the required license fee. The clerk shall also issue to the applicant a memorandum certificate for each taxicab authorized by the city council. 
(Code 1972, § 27-22) 
Sec. 22-44. - Same—Expiration, reinstatement. 
All certificates shall expire on December 31 of each year, including the year of issue, but may be reinstated by the city clerk for the following year, provided that there has been no revocation thereof and further provided that all license fees required to be paid have been paid. 
(Code 1972, § 27-23) 
Sec. 22-45. - Registration of vehicles—Required. 
(a)  Duty of operator. Prior to placing a taxicab in service, any operator shall register that vehicle with the traffic officer, providing a complete and true description of such vehicle to include the serial number, make, model and color. 
(b)  Duty of traffic officer. The traffic officer shall maintain a file on each operator, including the description of each vehicle registered as required by this section, and he may issue identification numbers for each registered vehicle. The officer may make inspections at any time to assure that the taxicabs in operation are registered and in full compliance with this article. 
(Code 1972, § 27-31) 
Sec. 22-46. - Same—Identification numbers to be affixed to vehicle. 
Should the traffic officer issue identification numbers, these numbers shall be affixed by decal or similar means in the rear window of the vehicle on the driver's side. 
(Code 1972, § 27-32) 
Sec. 22-47. - Insurance of vehicle; required. 
Every person operating a taxicab in the city or the owner of any such taxicab shall provide the traffic officer with a copy of the insurance certificate showing that such vehicle is properly insured in accordance with the laws of the state, and such insurance company shall be properly licensed to do business in the state and the city. 
(Code 1972, § 27-35) 
Sec. 22-48. - Cancellation of insurance, notice required. 
The city shall be given a minimum of ten days' written notice of cancellation of vehicular insurance covering the operation of taxicabs. 
(Code 1972, § 27-37) 
Sec. 22-49. - Suspension of unsafe vehicle from service. 
The traffic officer or the city council may suspend from operation any taxicab found to be unsafe, and any vehicle so suspended shall not be permitted to again operate until repaired and put in proper condition for use. Prior to returning to service, such taxicab shall be inspected and approved by the traffic officer. 
(Code 1972, § 27-38) 
Sec. 22-50. - Sale, trade, exchange of vehicle. 
(a)  Notice required. If any owner or operator of a taxicab in the city shall sell, grade or exchange any taxicab being operated in the city and substitute another car therefor, it shall be the duty of the seller to notify the traffic officer within 24 hours of the sale, trade or exchange of the vehicle, and such owner or operator shall provide the officer with the identification number of such vehicle under which the vehicle is identified on the insurance policy on file. 
(b)  Transfer of insurance required. It shall be the duty of such owner or operator of the car substituted to furnish the traffic officer written endorsement of the insurance company issuing the vehicular insurance policy showing that the additional vehicle is properly insured under the terms of the policy. 
(Code 1972, § 27-39) 
Sec. 22-51. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 03-06, § VII, adopted March 11, 2003, amended the Code by repealing former § 22-51 in its entirety. Former § 22-51 pertained to right of licensee to furnish additional service; and derived from the Code of 1972, § 27-40. 
Sec. 22-52. - Rates and charges—Contents of schedule, posting required. 
Each taxicab operator licensed in the city shall post, at a conspicuous place in his taxicabs, a schedule of rates, such schedule clearly showing distances and prices therefor. Each such operator shall furnish a similar copy of such rates so posted in his taxicabs to the traffic officer. 
(Code 1972, § 27-57) 
Sec. 22-53. - Same—Violations. 
It shall be unlawful for any taxicab owner or operator to fail to post or publish the rates as required in section 22-52 and, by himself or through his drivers, to charge rates in excess of those published. If the rates are not posted and/or there is an excessive charge, the city council may call for a hearing in which the owner or operator is allowed to appear and be heard and present evidence on the matter. If it is determined that this section or section 22-52 has been violated, the council may revoke or suspend such owner's or operator's license. 
(Code 1972, § 27-58) 
Sec. 22-54. - Maintenance of taxicabs, records by owners. 
Every owner of a taxicab or taxicab company shall comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  Condition of taxicab. All taxicabs shall be maintained in a clean and safe condition at all times. 
(2)  Record of calls. He shall keep a record of all telephone calls for taxicabs service for a minimum of 30 days for use, if needed, by the police department. 
(Code 1972, § 27-61) 
Sec. 22-55. - Offices below street level prohibited. 
Taxicab companies shall not be permitted to have their offices below street level. 
(Code 1972, § 27-63) 
Secs. 22-56—22-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVERS 

Sec. 22-71. - Permit—Required, application fee. 
Before any person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city, he shall first pay to the traffic officer a registration fee as set by the city council and shall make a written and signed application to such traffic officer which shall contain the following information: name, residence, telephone number, age, date of birth, height, weight, hair color, color of eyes, number of years experience driving motor vehicles, whether he has been convicted of any felonies, misdemeanors or traffic ordinance violations, and if so, giving the dates and details and any other information requested by the traffic officer. The applicant shall also provide the names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least two references who can answer questions related to the background investigation which will be conducted by the traffic officer. If the applicant desires a permit to drive for the owner of a taxicab business, the applicant shall include the name of such owner. Such permit shall be issued and renewed on an annual basis. 
(Code 1972, § 27-24) 
Sec. 22-72. - Same—Action upon application. 
(a)  Issuance of permit; contents. After receipt of the application for permit provided for in section 22-71, the traffic officer shall consider the same, and if satisfied from such application and other evidence that applicant is a fit and proper person to safely drive a taxicab in the city, and that application complies with the provisions of this article and the traffic ordinances of the city, the permit shall be granted the applicant and signed by the traffic officer. The permit shall contain the name and description of the applicant and such other data as the traffic officer deems proper. 
(b)  Denial of permit. The chief of police shall investigate each applicant for a taxicab license. He shall also check the record of each applicant for felony convictions and/or traffic violations. Any person who has been convicted of, pled guilty to or forfeited bonds as being in violation of traffic offenses totalling more than 20 points, as provided by state law within the five years immediately prior to his application for a license, shall not be entitled to a permit to operate a taxicab or vehicle for hire within the city. 
(Code 1972, § 27-25) 
Sec. 22-73. - Same—Posting inside taxicab. 
The name and picture of each taxicab driver, with his signature appearing thereon, shall be attached to the permit issued to such driver, and such permit, picture and signature shall be prominently displayed inside each taxicab such driver operates. 
(Code 1972, § 27-26) 
Sec. 22-74. - Same—Suspension, revocation. 
Each permit granted for the privilege of driving a taxicab upon the streets of the city is subject to suspension or revocation, or both, by the traffic officer whenever the holder of such permit violates or fails to comply with a provision of this article, whether or not there has been a trial of such driver before any court. The traffic officer shall notify such driver in writing of the suspension or revocation. 
(Code 1972, § 27-27) 
Sec. 22-75. - Same—Appeal from denial, suspension, revocation. 
Any person to whom the traffic officer has denied a permit to drive a taxicab, and any person whose permit has been suspended or revoked shall have the right to appeal to the city council, which may, by resolution, grant or deny relief as may appear proper to the council and in accordance with the terms and intent of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 27-28) 
Sec. 22-76. - Same—Extent of authority of traffic officer. 
Because of the necessity of providing for the public safety and the public health, and because the driving of taxicabs upon the streets of the city is a mere privilege and not a right, a wide discretion shall be vested in the traffic officer in granting of refusing permits, suspending and revoking such permits and carrying out the provisions and intent of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 27-29) 
Sec. 22-77. - Same—Extent of authority of council. 
The city council shall not be limited in the control over permits to operate taxicabs to cases appealed from the action of the traffic officer, nor to cases arising because of violations of the terms of this article. The council shall have the power to suspend or revoke any permit granted for the driving of a taxicab on city streets whenever it finds that such suspension or revocation would be in the public interest. 
(Code 1972, § 27-30) 
Sec. 22-78. - Health generally. 
(a)  All persons applying for permits to drive or already driving taxicabs on city streets shall be in good health and be capable of physically performing the work as a driver. 
(b)  No person shall drive a taxicab when on account of poor eyesight not corrected by glasses, or on account of bodily or mental infirmity, or being afflicted by infectious or contagious disease or for other reasons, he is unable safely to drive a taxicab upon such streets. 
(c)  Should the traffic officer have concerns about the capability of any applicant to comply with this section, he may require that such applicant, at his own expense, undergo a physical examination by a licensed physician. Refusal of the applicant to undergo the examination shall constitute grounds for denial of the permit. 
(Code 1972, § 27-42) 
Sec. 22-79. - Fingerprinting. 
No person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city until he has had his fingerprints taken by the police department of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 27-43) 
Sec. 22-80. - Effect of felony conviction. 
No person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city who has been convicted or pled guilty to an offense constituting a felony; however, if such person has had his civil and political rights restored and/or been given a pardon, such felony conviction will not bar such person from receiving a permit authorizing him to drive a taxicab in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 27-44) 
Sec. 22-81. - Appearance. 
All taxicab drivers shall be neat in appearance while on duty, clean in person and dress. No person shall operate a taxicab without shoes and each driver must wear a shirt, blouse or top. 
(Code 1972, § 27-45) 
Sec. 22-82. - Familiarity with ordinances required. 
No person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city until he has shown, upon examination by the traffic officer, a familiarity with the provisions of this article, the same to be furnished by the traffic officer to each driver. 
(Code 1972, § 27-46) 
Sec. 22-83. - Obedience to police. 
A person driving a taxicab upon the streets of the city shall bring the vehicle to a full stop immediately upon command of a member of the police department of the city or any other law enforcement officer, and shall proceed only as lawfully directed by such officer. 
(Code 1972, § 27-47) 
Sec. 22-84. - Driving while under the influence of alcoholic beverages and/or narcotics. 
No person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city while under the influence of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or who habitually uses alcoholic beverages or narcotics. 
(Code 1972, § 27-48) 
Sec. 22-85. - Transporting alcoholic beverages, narcotics. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a licensed taxicab service in the city or any driver operating a taxicab in the city under such license, knowingly to haul any form of alcoholic beverages or narcotics in such taxicab. 
(b)  Revocation of operator's license. If the driver of any taxicab in the city knowingly allows or permits alcoholic beverages or narcotics to be hauled in the taxicab operated by him, the holder or owner of the license issued by the city, under which such taxicab is being operated, shall forfeit his license and the license shall be automatically revoked. If any license is forfeited and revoked because a driver is guilty of hauling alcoholic beverages or narcotics, the licensee shall have the right of a hearing before the city council at such time and place as the city council may designate. Pending such hearing before the city council, the owner or holder of such license shall not operate the taxicab service under and by virtue of any such license. 
(c)  Forfeiture of driver's rights. It shall be unlawful for any driver guilty of knowingly hauling alcoholic beverages or narcotics in any taxicab driver by him to again drive a taxicab in the city. 
(Code 1972, § 27-49) 
Sec. 22-86. - Transporting prostitutes. 
No person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city transporting prostitutes or soliciting or transporting persons for the purposes of prostitution. 
(Code 1972, § 27-50) 
Sec. 22-87. - Cruising. 
No driver of a taxicab shall cruise in search of passengers at any time but shall proceed from an origin by the most convenient and direct route to the required destination. When a taxicab is empty of passengers it shall, if awaiting a radio call for another trip, remain parked at a convenient location in the general area of the last destination, or proceed directly to its headquarters or to a designated cab stand without soliciting passengers in route. 
(Code 1972, § 27-51) 
Sec. 22-88. - Number of passengers restricted. 
No person shall drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city when such vehicle contains passengers in excess of the maximum number for which the vehicle was designed. 
(Code 1972, § 27-52) 
Sec. 22-89. - Front seat passengers. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of a taxicab to permit a person to ride with him upon the front seat of the taxicab while operating in the city, unless the rear seat of such taxicab is fully occupied by passengers; however, the driver may require a passenger to ride in the front seat if the driver feels a concern for his personal safety. The driver may also allow a physically incapacitated person to ride in the front seat. In making charges under this section, the investigating officer shall consider all circumstances including weather conditions and the health and infirmity of passengers or other valid reasons for the driver to allow passengers in the front seat. 
(Code 1972, § 27-53) 
Sec. 22-90. - Refusal to transport orderly passengers. 
No driver of a taxicab shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly persons upon request unless such taxicab is previously engaged or is unable or forbidden to do so by provisions of city ordinances or by state law. 
(Code 1972, § 27-54) 
Sec. 22-91. - Receipt, discharge of passengers. 
Drivers of taxicabs shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway but shall drive to the sidewalk or curb on the right-hand side of such roadway to receive and discharge passengers. 
(Code 1972, § 27-56) 
Sec. 22-92. - Inspection of taxicab, driver. 
Every person applying for a permit to drive or who drives a taxicab upon the streets of the city must submit himself and the taxicab driven by him to the inspection of the traffic officer whenever so directed by such officer. 
(Code 1972, § 27-60) 
Secs. 22-93—22-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIMOUSINES 

Sec. 22-101. - Definitions. 
Limousine means any motor vehicle that meets the manufacturer's specifications for a luxury limousine with a designed seating capacity for no more than ten passengers and with a minimum of five seats located behind the operator of the vehicle, and which does not have a door at the rear of the vehicle designated to allow passenger entry or exit; further, no vehicle shall be permitted to operate both as a taxicab and a limousine. 
Limousine carrier means any person operating a service regularly rendered to the public by furnishing transportation as a motor common carrier for hire, not over fixed routes, by means of limousines, or extended limousines, on the basis of verbal contract or written contract. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, or joint-stock association, and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee, or personal representative thereof. 
(Ord. No. 03-06, § VIII, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 22-102. - Occupational taxes. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-7-85.11, limousine carriers shall be subject to the occupational taxes set forth in article I of chapter 3 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Newnan. 
(Ord. No. 03-06, § VIII, 3-11-03) 
Sec. 22-103. - Regulatory fee. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-7-85.11, the state having preempted the regulation of limousine carriers, no regulatory fees or requirements for operation shall be imposed on limousine businesses except as otherwise provided by law, and the provisions of articles I and II of this chapter, if not so pre-empted, shall then apply. 
(Ord. No. 03-06, § VIII, 3-11-03) 
Secs. 22-104—22-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES 

Sec. 22-120. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except, where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Animal warden shall mean the animal control officer of the city. 
Chief of police shall mean the chief of police of the city. 
City shall mean the City of Newnan, Georgia. 
City clerk shall mean the city clerk of the city. 
City manager shall mean the city manager of the city. 
Company means the holder of a license to operate a horse-drawn carriage business under the provisions of this article whether a person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
Draft animal means a horse, mule or other beast of burden, used for the drawing of horse-drawn carriage. 
Draft animal permit means the written document issued by the city identifying a draft animal drawing a horse-drawn carriage for a designated licensed company within the city. 
Driver means any person who drives or operates a horse-drawn carriage on the streets of the city for a licensed company. 
Driver's permit means the written authority granted by the city for an individual to drive or operate a horse-drawn carriage within the city. 
Horse-drawn carriage means any hack or carriage, which is operated by being drawn by a horse, mule or other beast of burden, for the transportation for hire of passengers. 
Inspector (chief of police or his designee) means the individual employee or organizational unit of the city charged with the responsibility for enforcing this article, except for specific responsibilities otherwise provided in this article. 
License means the right and privilege granted by the city for the operation of a business incorporating the use of one or more horse-drawn carriages within the corporate limits of the city. 
Stand means a public place alongside the curb of a street or elsewhere, which has been designated by the mayor and council, as reserved exclusively for the use of horse-drawn carriages. 
Street shall mean and include any street, alley, lane, avenue, court of public place within the city. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-121. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Violation of this article may be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of the license issued under this article. Penalties for violation of this article are as follows: 
(1)  First offense, a fine of ..... $250.00 
(2)  Second offense, a fine of ..... 750.00 
(3)  Third offense ..... license revoked 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-122. - Licensing of horse-drawn carriage companies. 
(a)  License. 
(1)  Required. No person shall operate a business involving the use of one or more horse-drawn carriages on the streets of the city unless a license for such business has first been granted by the city. The license shall be effective only for the calendar year stated in the license, unless suspended or revoked sooner as provided by ordinance. The annual license fee shall be as established from time to time by the mayor and council. In addition, the licensee shall file and pay annually the occupational tax fee due the city. 
(2)  Application. Application for the license shall be made on forms provided by the city clerk and shall provide such information as is required for other business license applications, and such additional information as may be necessary to define completely the business operation. 
(3)  Certification of EIA. Each applicant must produce, if demanded by the animal warden, inspector or city manager, a valid equine infectious anemia (EIA) certification for each animal. 
(b)  Operating regulations. In addition to the license requirements imposed in this section, no license shall be issued to any carriage operator unless the operator complies with the following operating regulations: 
(1)  A licensed veterinarian shall certify, after due and proper inspection, the good health of each draft animal before it is placed into service. One such health inspection shall be required for each animal within six months of the application for a license and annually thereafter upon renewal of license, if requested by the animal warden, inspector or city manager. 
(2)  Unless written approval is given by a licensed veterinarian, no animal having open sores or wounds or any disease or ailment shall be permitted to be in service on the streets of the city. 
(3)  Each draft animal shall have its hooves properly trimmed and shod for street surfaces. 
(4)  Each animal shall be groomed daily and not have fungus, dandruff, or a dirty coat. 
(5)  Harnesses shall be properly fitted, maintained, and oiled so that no irritating material will come in direct contact with the animal. 
(6)  No driver may use more than a light touch of the whip upon any animal, and no driver or other persons may forcefully strike an animal, and make movements or noise intended to frighten or harm an animal. 
(7)  No driver shall permit an animal to pull a carriage at a speed faster than a slow trot, except in extreme emergency situations. 
(8)  No animal shall be subject to any condition or treatment, whether in service or out of service, which will impair the good health and physical condition of that animal. 
(9)  Adequate water shall be provided. 
(10)  Ventilation adequate to ensure the health and comfort of animals shall be provided. 
(11)  Food shall be free of contamination. 
(12)  All laws as cited as the "Humane Care for Equines Act" (O.C.G.A. § 4-13-1 et seq.), as well as all other state and federal laws governing equines. 
(13)  No one animal may be worked for more than eight hours per day. The driver must keep a log of starting and ending times for each animal. Such log should be kept in a bound book form and stored on the carriage being pulled. 
(14)  No driver shall work an animal pulling a horse-drawn carriage when the outside temperature exceeds 90 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(15)  No sound device will be used that transmits volume more than 25 feet from the carriage. 
(c)  Inspection of operating practices. The inspector shall be empowered to inspect all operating practices of any carriage company to ensure continuous compliance with this article. 
(d)  Failure to comply with article provisions; non-issuance. Any applicant who refuses or fails to comply with the requirements of this article shall not be issued a business license until proof of compliance is presented by the applicant and certified by the inspector. The licensing requirements of this section shall be ongoing as requirements for continuous operation. 
(e)  Suspension. The chief of police and/or city manager may, upon recommendation of the inspector, temporarily suspend any carriage company license for violation of the provisions of this article, subject to license revocation action. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-123. - Insurance. 
(a)  Indemnity for benefit of city. Any horse-drawn carriage company operating under this article shall hold the city, its officers, agents, servants and employees, harmless against any and all liability, loss, damages or expenses which may accrue to the city by reason of negligence, default or misconduct of the company in connection with the rights granted to such company under this article. Nothing this article shall be considered to make the city, its officers, agents, servants or employees liable for damages because of any negligent act or omission or commission by any horse-drawn carriage company, its servants, agents, drivers or other employees, during the operation by the company of a horse-drawn carriage business or service, either in respect to injury to persons or with respect to damage to property which may be sustained. 
(b)  Insurance for benefit of passengers. Any horse-drawn carriage company desiring a license to do business shall give and maintain a policy of indemnity from an insurance company authorized to do business in the state for each vehicle in use as a horse-drawn carriage. The minimum coverage shall be $100,000.00 for bodily injury to any one person, $300,000.00 for injury to more than one person, which are sustained in the same accident, and $50,000.00 for property damage resulting from one accident. The indemnity insurance shall inure to the benefit of any person who shall be injured or who shall sustain damage to property caused by the negligence of a horse-drawn carriage company, its servants or agents. 
(c)  Blanket policy. Any company or person operating a horse-drawn carriage in the city shall give a separate policy of indemnity insurance for each separate horse-drawn carriage for hire, except where such company or person actually owns or holds legal title to more than one horse-drawn carriage, in which event such company or person may give one policy of indemnity insurance covering all the horse-drawn carriages actually owned. This latter provision, however, shall not apply to any group of persons separately owning horse-drawn carriages who may be jointly operating or doing business under a licensed horse-drawn carriage name. 
(d)  Notice when avoided. Before any policy of insurance required by this article is voided for any cause, nonpayment of premium or otherwise, notice shall be given by the licensee in writing, to the city clerk at least five days before the policy shall take effect. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-124. - Driver's permits. 
(a)  Driver's permits. 
(1)  Required. No person shall operate a horse-drawn carriage for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who owns or operates a horse-drawn carriage company shall permit a horse-drawn carriage to be driven, and no horse-drawn carriage operating under a horse-drawn carriage company licensed by the city shall be driven at any time for hire, unless the driver of the horse-drawn carriage shall first have obtained and shall have then in force a horse-drawn carriage driver's permit issued under the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Application. Any person desiring a permit required by this article shall submit an application in writing to the chief of police on a form to be furnished by the chief of police. The application shall be made under oath and shall state the age of the applicant, date of birth, his address, and whether he has been convicted of a violation of any of the laws of the state or of this article or other ordinances of the city, and, if so, when and of what offense, and the sentence of the court. 
(3)  Qualifications of applicant. An applicant for a driver's permit under this article must not be less than 18 years of age, with no physical infirmities which might make the applicant an unsafe or unsatisfactory horse-drawn carriage driver. The applicant shall not have been convicted of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating beverages or drugs within two years prior to the date of the application for such permit, or have been convicted of reckless driving within one year prior to the date of the application for such permit, or been convicted of any of these offenses three or more times within three years prior to the date of the application for such permit. Nor shall a permit be issued to any person who has within three years prior to the date of the application for such permit been convicted of any crime relating to transporting persons for immoral purposes (prostitution, solicitation for prostitution, or any sex related offense), or who has within three years prior to the date of the application for such permit have been convicted, of, been on probation, parole, or served time on a sentence for a felony. A plea of nolo contendere to any of the offenses set out in this section shall be deemed a conviction. [The applicant shall] be a citizen of the United States or an alien admitted for permanent residence or who has otherwise been granted employment authorization by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Services. 
(4)  Fee. Before any permit is granted under this article, a driver's permit fee, in the amount of $35.00 shall be paid by the applicant. This fee shall include the cost of a criminal history background check. 
(5)  Current state driver's license required. Any person applying for a horse-drawn carriage driver's permit under this article must show that he has a current motor vehicle operator's license issued or approved by the state, and that the license is not under suspension or revocation. Applicant must furnish at least a five-year driver's history upon application. 
(6)  Examination of applicant. It shall be the duty of the chief of police or his designee to examine the applicant, criminal and traffic record, and other vouchers, and thereafter recommend to the chief of police or his designee to grant or refuse the permit. In the event of a refusal by the chief of police or his designee to grant a permit, the applicant shall have the right to enter an appeal to the city manager. Such appeal shall be filed in writing to the city manager within ten calendar days from the date of refusal to grant the permit. The city manager must convene an appeals hearing within 20 calendar days from receipt of the written appeal. Within ten calendar days from the appeals hearing, the city manager shall render a written decision as to the city manager's decision on the appeal. 
(7)  Displayed in horse-drawn carriage. The permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be placed in the horse-drawn carriage to be operated by the holder of the permit. 
(8)  Alteration. It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to alter, deface, obliterate or destroy a horse-drawn carriage driver's permit, or cause or allow the same. 
(9)  Transfer. Any horse-drawn carriage driver's permit issued under this article is not transferable, and is to be used solely by the person to whom it is issued. 
(10)  Duration. Any horse-drawn carriage driver's permit shall be valid for that calendar year. Permits may be renewed upon application and payment of the required fee, unless the permit for the preceding period has been revoked or is under suspension. 
(11)  Suspension. The inspector shall recommend to the chief of police to suspend the driver's permit for the following reasons: 
a.  Making any false statement in the application for the person; or 
b.  Operating a horse-drawn carriage in violation of any provision of this article or of state law. 
The suspension by the chief of police shall be lifted upon dismissal or dropping of the charges described upon correction of the violation of any provision of this article, upon ruling in favor of the driver in any appeal hearing before the city manager, or at the expiration of 60 days from the date of suspension. From the decision to suspend a permit, the holder of such permit shall have the right to appeal the decision of the chief of police to the city manager within ten calendar days from the date of suspension, and the city manager must convene an appeals hearing within 20 calendar days from receipt of the filing by the city clerk of the written appeal. Within ten calendar days from the appeals hearing, the city manager shall render a written decision on the appeal. 
(12)  Revocation. If any driver holding a permit under this article at any time ceases to meet the qualifications described in subsection (c) of this section or fails to operate his horse-drawn carriage in accordance with the provisions of this article, the city manager shall be empowered to permanently revoke the permit. The holder of such permit shall have the right to appeal the decision of the city manager to the mayor and council in the manner prescribed in subsection (14) of this section. 
(13)  Driving after revocation or suspension. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a horse-drawn carriage for hire for the carriage of passengers during any period in which his permit to do so is suspended or revoked in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(14)  Appeals. Any appeal of a decision made by the chief of police to revoke a horse-drawn carriage driver's permit, pursuant to this section, shall be made in writing to the city manager within ten calendar days of the ruling. The city manager must convene an appeals hearing within 20 calendar days from the filing with the chief of police of the written appeal. The appellant shall have the right to be represented by counsel. Within ten calendar days from the appeals hearing; the city manager shall render a written decision on the appeal. 
(b)  Animal permits. 
(1)  Permits required. No draft animal shall be allowed to draw a horse-drawn carriage for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who holds a horse-drawn carriage license pursuant to this chapter shall permit any draft animal to draw a horse-drawn carriage at any time for hire, unless the license holder of the horse-drawn carriage has obtained and have in force a horse-drawn carriage draft animal permit issued under the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Application. Any person desiring a permit required by this section shall submit an application in writing to the chief of police on a form furnished by the chief of police. The application shall be made under oath and shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
a.  The name and description of the draft animal; 
b.  Date of birth of the draft animal; 
c.  Name and address of the owner of the draft animal; 
d.  The name and license number of the horse-carriage company for whom the draw animal shall labor; and 
e.  A photograph of the draft animal. 
(3)  Draft animal's permit fee. Before any permit is granted under this section, an administrative fee for the draft animal permit in the amount of $10.00 shall be paid by the applicant. 
(4)  Permit to be displayed in horse-drawn carriage. The permit issued under the provisions of this section shall be placed in the horse-drawn carriage then being drawn by the permitted draft animal. 
(5)  Alteration of permits prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to alter, deface, obliterate or destroy a horse-drawn carriage draft animal permit, or cause or allow the same. 
(6)  Permit not transferable. Any horse-drawn carriage draft animal's permit issued under this section is not transferable, from draft animal to draft animal, and is to be used solely by the draft animal for which it is issued. 
(7)  Duration of permit. Any horse-drawn carriage draft animal's permit shall be valid for that calendar year. Permits may be renewed, upon application and payment of the required fee. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-125. - Identification and marking generally. 
Every horse-drawn carriage shall have a sign plainly painted or affixed in an acceptable manner on the rear of each vehicle. The sign shall contain the full name of the horse-drawn carriage company operating the vehicle. Additionally, the sign shall conform with all sign standards for the city and be approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-126. - Safe mechanical condition of required. 
Every horse-drawn carriage operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in a safe mechanical condition, with all safety equipment remaining intact and operative at all times when the horse-drawn carriage is in service. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-127. - Cleanliness required. 
Each vehicle operating under this article shall be kept painted and in a clean and sanitary condition, free of litter and debris, and at all times suitable for public transportation of passengers. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-128. - Vehicle inspections required. 
Each horse-drawn carriage may be inspected by the inspector for compliance with the provisions of this article and shall pass the inspection before the vehicle may be used as a horse-drawn carriage in the city. Each horse-drawn carriage involved in an accident shall be inspected by the inspector before it may be returned to service transporting passengers for hire. Inspections of the horse-drawn carriages may be done at any time by the inspector. Company is required to notify the chief of police anytime a carriage used in the city is involved in an accident. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-129. - Authority for removal from streets. 
The inspector shall have the authority to remove from operation on the streets of the city any vehicle used as a horse-drawn carriage that is in violation of this article, and to prohibit operation of the horse-drawn carriage until all deficiencies have been corrected. An order of the inspector to remove a vehicle from the streets may be appealed to the chief of police. The appeal must be made in writing to the chief of police no later than ten calendar days after the inspector has exercised his authority in removing a horse-drawn carriage from the street for violation of this article. The chief of police must convene a hearing within ten calendar days of receipt of the appeal, and must render a written decision to the appellant within ten calendar days of the close of the hearing. The decision of the chief of police may be appealed to the city manager, as provided for in section 22-124(a)(14). 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-130. - Rates of fare; rate cared required. 
No owner or driver of a horse-drawn carriage shall charge a greater sum for the use of the horse-drawn carriage than in accordance with the published and advertised rates, which shall be placed in or near each horse drawn carriage. Rates shall be displayed in such place as to be conspicuous and to be in clear view of all passengers, in or near the horse drawn carriage. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-131. - Driver not to leave vehicle while waiting to be hired. 
It is unlawful for any driver of any horse-drawn carriage to leave the vehicle or the immediate premises of the vehicle, while the vehicle is parked and while waiting to be hired. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-132. - Restriction on number of passengers. 
No driver shall permit more persons to be carried in a horse-drawn carriage as passengers than the seating capacity of the horse-drawn carriage, not to exceed ten people, including the driver. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-133. - Refusal to carry orderly passengers. 
No driver shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request, unless previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this article to do so. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-134. - Weight restrictions. 
The aggregate weight of the carriage, passengers and driver shall not exceed two times the body weight of the horse. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-135. - Movement of carriage prohibited under certain circumstances. 
No driver shall collect fares, make change, or take on or discharge passengers while his horse-drawn carriage is in motion. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-136. - Property left in carriage by passenger. 
Any horse-drawn carriage driver or operator, discovering in any horse-drawn carriage under his control, personal property which was lost or left by a passenger of such horse-drawn carriage, shall report the loss, and deliver all the property to the police department within two hours after the discovery of the property. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-137. - Safety equipment required. 
(a)  Each horse-drawn carriage shall be equipped with electrically powered lights or lanterns and reflectors. Such lights shall be in use when operating during the hours of darkness and when raining. The lights and reflectors shall be mounted so that they are visible from a distance of 500 feet in all directions. Each horse-drawn carriage shall have on board at all times a first aid kit. 
(b)  Each horse-drawn carriage shall be equipped with a suitable friction braking system, which will enable the carriage to stop. Such braking system shall be functional and operative at all times. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-138. - Area of operation. 
The inspector or chief of police or his designee may elect to set a route for horse-drawn carriages, to include a designated site for a loading and unloading stand. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-139. - Sanitation requirements. 
Manure and urine must be immediately treated with a chemical deodorizing solution, and manure must be removed immediately from the street by the carriage operator. Each carriage must be equipped with a suitable scoop shovel and airtight container. Horse diapers, which prevent excrement from being deposited on the street surface, may be used in lieu of a scoop shovel and an airtight container at the option of the operator. In the case of horse diapers, the diapers must be approved for efficiency by the inspector before they are used. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-140. - Traffic violations. 
(a)  Horse-drawn carriages shall be prohibited from stopping in traffic or delaying any on-street traffic for the purposes of loading and unloading passengers or for any other purpose. 
(b)  Every person riding any animal upon a roadway and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle within the city limits of the city shall be subject to the provisions of this article and shall operate the vehicles in accordance with the traffic laws of the city, as well as the state. 
(c)  Due to the nature of operating animal-drawn vehicles in areas of congestion and heavy traffic within the city, it shall be unlawful to operate the animal-drawn vehicles except when the animals are under complete control at all times, and shall be operated with extra caution and due care for the safety of others. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-141. - Impediment of traffic flow. 
It shall be unlawful for any horse-drawn carriage to willfully impede the normal flow of traffic on any city street, alley or thoroughfare at any time. Horse-drawn carriages will be required to pull immediately to the nearest curb area when one or more vehicles are unable to safely pass or continue in normal traffic flow. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-142. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Hours of operation: 

 
(b)  Hours of operation may be altered for special events planned in the downtown district only upon approval by the mayor and council. 
(c)  Private hires will be exempt from hours of operation from 8:00 a.m. until regular business hours subject to the requirements and restrictions contained in section 22-143. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-143. - Travel routes allowed. 
(a)  Horse drawn carriages will be allowed to travel only inside of the following areas: 
College Street from Clark Street to Spring Street to First Avenue to LaGrange Street, to Nimmons Street, to Greenville Street, to Salbide Avenue, to Perry Street, to Madison Street, to Jefferson Street, to Wesley Street, to College Street. 
(b)  Private hire: If someone wishes to hire the company for private use, the company must submit a request for an unloading site for the animal and carriage. The company must take the most direct route from their departure address to their destination address. The company must notify and receive approval from the chief of police of the proposed route to be used as soon as the route is known, but not less than one day. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-144. - Place of business required. 
If anyone operates a horse drawn carriage more than five days a week, the owner thereof shall maintain a place of business from a building located on private property with adequate off-street parking for all horse-drawn carriages not in service and adequate retention facilities for draft animals not in service within a commercially zoned district in which horse-drawn carriages for hire is a permitted use in accordance with the most recently adopted zoning map and have first obtained certification of compliance from the city zoning administrator. The location shall not be moved, except by the approved transfer of the license to another location. No draft animals shall be permitted to remain overnight at the location of the place of business. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-145. - Limits to the number of horse-drawn carriages. 
It shall be unlawful for any horse-drawn carriage company to operate more than two horse-drawn carriages for hire on the streets of the city at any given time. The city clerk may authorize more than two carriages to operate upon the company's request. Such request shall be in writing indicating the company's needs for additional carriages. The city clerk may approve the request for special events or with respect to special circumstances upon approval from the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06) 
Sec. 22-146. - Compliance required. 
Failure to comply with this article or any of the laws, ordinances and regulations of this city can result in the revocation of permit and citation and punishment in municipal court as set forth in section 1-14 of the city's Code of Ordinances. Any ordinance or laws of this city, state of federal agency which governs the treatment of animals, including horses or other animals of burden, must be complied with by the horse-drawn carriage operator, passengers or agents of the horse-drawn carriage company. 
(Ord. No. 06-3, § 1, 2-14-06)
